sentences.zh: 周后稷，名棄。

translations.text: Zhou's Houji was named Qi (meaning "Abandoned").

sentences.zh: 其母有邰氏女，曰姜原。

translations.text: His mother was a woman of the Youtai clan, named Jiang Yuan.

sentences.zh: 姜原為帝嚳元妃。

translations.text: Jiang Yuan was the principal consort of Emperor Ku.

sentences.zh: 姜原出野，見巨人跡，心忻然說，欲踐之，踐之而身動如孕者。

translations.text: Jiang Yuan went out to the fields and saw a giant's footprint; her heart was delighted, and she wanted to step in it. When she stepped in it, her body stirred as if she were pregnant.

sentences.zh: 居期而生子，以為不祥，棄之隘巷，馬牛過者皆辟不踐；

translations.text: After the full term she gave birth to a son; considering this inauspicious, she abandoned him in a narrow alley, but horses and oxen that passed all avoided him and did not trample him.

sentences.zh: 徙置之林中，適會山林多人，遷之；

translations.text: She moved and placed him in the forest, but it happened that many people were in the mountains and forests, so she moved him again.

sentences.zh: 而棄渠中冰上，飛鳥以其翼覆薦之。

translations.text: Then she abandoned him on the ice in a ditch, but flying birds covered and protected him with their wings.

sentences.zh: 姜原以為神，遂收養長之。

translations.text: Jiang Yuan considered this divine intervention, and thereupon took him in and raised him.

sentences.zh: 初欲棄之，因名曰棄。

translations.text: Because she had initially wanted to abandon him, she named him Qi ("Abandoned").

Zhou's Houji was named Qi (meaning "Abandoned"). His mother was a woman of the Youtai clan, named Jiang Yuan. Jiang Yuan was the principal consort of Emperor Ku. Jiang Yuan went out to the fields and saw a giant's footprint; her heart was delighted, and she wanted to step in it. When she stepped in it, her body stirred as if she were pregnant. After the full term she gave birth to a son; considering this inauspicious, she abandoned him in a narrow alley, but horses and oxen that passed all avoided him and did not trample him. She moved and placed him in the forest, but it happened that many people were in the mountains and forests, so she moved him again. Then she abandoned him on the ice in a ditch, but flying birds covered and protected him with their wings. Jiang Yuan considered this divine intervention, and thereupon took him in and raised him. Because she had initially wanted to abandon him, she named him Qi ("Abandoned").

sentences.zh: 棄為兒時，屹如巨人之志。

translations.text: When Qi was a child, he was firm and resolute like a great man.

sentences.zh: 其游戲，好種樹麻、菽，麻、菽美。

translations.text: In his play, he loved to plant hemp and beans, and the hemp and beans grew beautifully.

sentences.zh: 及為成人，遂好耕農，相地之宜，宜穀者稼穡焉，民皆法則之。

translations.text: When he became an adult, he came to love agriculture, examined the suitability of land, and planted crops where grain was suitable; the people all took him as their model.

sentences.zh: 帝堯聞之，舉棄為農師，天下得其利，有功。

translations.text: Emperor Yao heard of this and appointed Qi as Minister of Agriculture; all under Heaven benefited from this, and he had merit.

sentences.zh: 帝舜曰：「棄，黎民始饑，爾后稷播時百穀。」

translations.text: Emperor Shun said: "Qi, the common people were suffering from hunger; you, as Houji, sowed the various grains in their proper seasons."

sentences.zh: 封棄於邰，號曰后稷，別姓姬氏。

translations.text: He enfeoffed Qi at Tai, titled him Houji, and gave him the separate surname Ji.

sentences.zh: 后稷之興，在陶唐﹑虞﹑夏之際，皆有令德。

translations.text: Houji's rise occurred during the time of Taotang (Yao), Yu (Shun), and Xia; all had excellent virtue.

When Qi was a child, he was firm and resolute like a great man. In his play, he loved to plant hemp and beans, and the hemp and beans grew beautifully. When he became an adult, he came to love agriculture, examined the suitability of land, and planted crops where grain was suitable; the people all took him as their model. Emperor Yao heard of this and appointed Qi as Minister of Agriculture; all under Heaven benefited from this, and he had merit. Emperor Shun said: "Qi, the common people were suffering from hunger; you, as Houji, sowed the various grains in their proper seasons."  He enfeoffed Qi at Tai, titled him Houji, and gave him the separate surname Ji. Houji's rise occurred during the time of Taotang (Yao), Yu (Shun), and Xia; all had excellent virtue.

sentences.zh: 后稷卒，子不窋立。

translations.text: When Houji died, his son Buzhu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 不窋末年，夏后氏政衰，去稷不務，不窋以失其官而犇戎狄之間。

translations.text: In Buzhu's final years, the government of the Xia declined; they abandoned the office of Ji and did not attend to it, so Buzhu lost his office and fled to live among the Rong and Di tribes.

sentences.zh: 不窋卒，子鞠立。

translations.text: When Buzhu died, his son Ju succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 鞠卒，子公劉立。

translations.text: When Ju died, his son Gongliu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 公劉雖在戎狄之間，復修后稷之業，務耕種，行地宜，自漆、沮度渭，取材用，行者有資，居者有畜積，民賴其慶。

translations.text: Although Gongliu was among the Rong and Di, he restored Houji's work, devoted himself to plowing and planting, practiced suitability of land, crossed the Wei River from the Qi and Ju rivers, obtained useful materials, so that travelers had provisions and residents had stored supplies, and the people relied on his blessings.

sentences.zh: 百姓懷之，多徙而保歸焉。

translations.text: The common people cherished him, and many migrated to seek refuge and return to him.

sentences.zh: 周道之興自此始，故詩人歌樂思其德。

translations.text: The rise of the Zhou way began from this point, therefore poets sang joyfully in remembrance of his virtue.

sentences.zh: 公劉卒，子慶節立，國於豳。

translations.text: When Gongliu died, his son Qingjie succeeded him and established his state at Bin.

When Houji died, his son Buzhu succeeded him. In Buzhu's final years, the government of the Xia declined; they abandoned the office of Ji and did not attend to it, so Buzhu lost his office and fled to live among the Rong and Di tribes. When Buzhu died, his son Ju succeeded him. When Ju died, his son Gongliu succeeded him. Although Gongliu was among the Rong and Di, he restored Houji's work, devoted himself to plowing and planting, practiced suitability of land, crossed the Wei River from the Qi and Ju rivers, obtained useful materials, so that travelers had provisions and residents had stored supplies, and the people relied on his blessings. The common people cherished him, and many migrated to seek refuge and return to him. The rise of the Zhou way began from this point, therefore poets sang joyfully in remembrance of his virtue. When Gongliu died, his son Qingjie succeeded him and established his state at Bin.

sentences.zh: 慶節卒，子皇仆立。

translations.text: When Qingjie died, his son Huangpu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 皇仆卒，子差弗立。

translations.text: When Huangpu died, his son Chafu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 差弗卒，子毀隃立。

translations.text: When Chafu died, his son Huiyu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 毀隃卒，子公非立。

translations.text: When Huiyu died, his son Gongfei succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 公非卒，子高圉立。

translations.text: When Gongfei died, his son Gaoyu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 高圉卒，子亞圉立。

translations.text: When Gaoyu died, his son Yayu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 亞圉卒，子公叔祖類立。

translations.text: When Yayu died, his son Gongshu Zulei succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 公叔祖類卒，子古公亶父立。

translations.text: When Gongshu Zulei died, his son Gugong Danfu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 古公亶父復修后稷、公劉之業，積德行義，國人皆戴之。

translations.text: Gugong Danfu again restored the work of Houji and Gongliu, accumulated virtue and practiced righteousness, and all the people of the state honored him.

sentences.zh: 薰育戎狄攻之，欲得財物，予之。

translations.text: The Xunyu Rong and Di tribes attacked him, wanting to obtain wealth and goods, so he gave it to them.

sentences.zh: 已復攻，欲得地與民。

translations.text: But they attacked again, wanting to obtain land and people.

sentences.zh: 民皆怒，欲戰。

translations.text: The people were all angry and wanted to fight.

sentences.zh: 古公曰：「有民立君，將以利之。

translations.text: Gugong said: "When the people establish a ruler, it is in order to benefit them.

sentences.zh: 今戎狄所為攻戰，以吾地與民。

translations.text: Now the Rong and Di attack and make war for my land and people.

sentences.zh: 民之在我，與其在彼，何異。

translations.text: Whether the people are with me or with them, what difference does it make?

sentences.zh: 民欲以我故戰，殺人父子而君之，予不忍為。」

translations.text: If the people want to fight on my account, killing fathers and sons in order to have me as ruler, I cannot bear to do this."

sentences.zh: 乃與私屬遂去豳，度漆、沮，踰梁山，止於岐下。

translations.text: Thereupon, with his close followers, he left Bin, crossed the Qi and Ju rivers, went over Mount Liang, and stopped at the foot of Mount Qi.

sentences.zh: 豳人舉國扶老攜弱，盡復歸古公於岐下。

translations.text: The people of Bin, the entire state supporting the old and leading the young, all returned to Gugong at the foot of Mount Qi.

sentences.zh: 及他旁國聞古公仁，亦多歸之。

translations.text: When other neighboring states heard of Gugong's benevolence, many also came to him.

sentences.zh: 於是古公乃貶戎狄之俗，而營筑城郭室屋，而邑別居之。

translations.text: Thereupon Gugong rejected the customs of the Rong and Di, constructed city walls and houses, and had people settle separately in towns.

sentences.zh: 作五官有司。

translations.text: He established the five offices with their officials.

sentences.zh: 民皆歌樂之，頌其德。

translations.text: The people all sang joyfully of him and praised his virtue.

When Qingjie died, his son Huangpu succeeded him. When Huangpu died, his son Chafu succeeded him. When Chafu died, his son Huiyu succeeded him. When Huiyu died, his son Gongfei succeeded him. When Gongfei died, his son Gaoyu succeeded him. When Gaoyu died, his son Yayu succeeded him. When Yayu died, his son Gongshu Zulei succeeded him. When Gongshu Zulei died, his son Gugong Danfu succeeded him. Gugong Danfu again restored the work of Houji and Gongliu, accumulated virtue and practiced righteousness, and all the people of the state honored him. The Xunyu Rong and Di tribes attacked him, wanting to obtain wealth and goods, so he gave it to them. But they attacked again, wanting to obtain land and people. The people were all angry and wanted to fight. Gugong said: "When the people establish a ruler, it is in order to benefit them. Now the Rong and Di attack and make war for my land and people. Whether the people are with me or with them, what difference does it make? If the people want to fight on my account, killing fathers and sons in order to have me as ruler, I cannot bear to do this."  Thereupon, with his close followers, he left Bin, crossed the Qi and Ju rivers, went over Mount Liang, and stopped at the foot of Mount Qi. The people of Bin, the entire state supporting the old and leading the young, all returned to Gugong at the foot of Mount Qi. When other neighboring states heard of Gugong's benevolence, many also came to him. Thereupon Gugong rejected the customs of the Rong and Di, constructed city walls and houses, and had people settle separately in towns. He established the five offices with their officials. The people all sang joyfully of him and praised his virtue.

sentences.zh: 古公有長子曰太伯，次曰虞仲。

translations.text: Gugong had an eldest son named Taibo and a second son named Yuzhong.

sentences.zh: 太姜生少子季歷，季歷娶太任，皆賢婦人，生昌，有聖瑞。

translations.text: Taijiang gave birth to a youngest son, Jili; Jili married Tairen, both virtuous women, and they gave birth to Chang, who displayed sacred auspicious signs.

sentences.zh: 古公曰：「我世當有興者，其在昌乎？」

translations.text: Gugong said: "Our lineage shall have one who brings prosperity; will it be in Chang?"

sentences.zh: 長子太伯、虞仲知古公欲立季歷以傳昌，乃二人亡如荊蠻，文身斷髪，以讓季歷。

translations.text: The eldest sons Taibo and Yuzhong knew that Gugong wished to install Jili in order to transmit succession to Chang, so the two fled to the Jing and Man tribes, tattooed their bodies and cut their hair, thereby yielding to Jili.

Gugong had an eldest son named Taibo and a second son named Yuzhong. Taijiang gave birth to a youngest son, Jili; Jili married Tairen, both virtuous women, and they gave birth to Chang, who displayed sacred auspicious signs. Gugong said: "Our lineage shall have one who brings prosperity; will it be in Chang?"  The eldest sons Taibo and Yuzhong knew that Gugong wished to install Jili in order to transmit succession to Chang, so the two fled to the Jing and Man tribes, tattooed their bodies and cut their hair, thereby yielding to Jili.

sentences.zh: 古公卒，季歷立，是為公季。

translations.text: When Gugong died, Jili succeeded him; this was Gongji.

sentences.zh: 公季修古公遺道，篤於行義，諸侯順之。

translations.text: Gongji cultivated Gugong's legacy way, was devoted to practicing righteousness, and the feudal lords submitted to him.
When Gugong died, Jili succeeded him; this was Gongji. Gongji cultivated Gugong's legacy way, was devoted to practicing righteousness, and the feudal lords submitted to him.

sentences.zh: 公季卒，子昌立，是為西伯。

translations.text: When Gongji died, his son Chang succeeded him; this was the Western Earl.

sentences.zh: 西伯曰文王，遵后稷、公劉之業，則古公、公季之法，篤仁，敬老，慈少。

translations.text: The Western Earl was called King Wen; he followed the work of Houji and Gongliu, modeled himself on the methods of Gugong and Gongji, was devoted to benevolence, revered the old, and showed kindness to the young.

sentences.zh: 禮下賢者，日中不暇食以待士，士以此多歸之。

translations.text: He treated worthy men with courtesy, had no leisure to eat at midday while receiving scholars, and scholars for this reason came to him in great numbers.

sentences.zh: 伯夷、叔齊在孤竹，聞西伯善養老，盍往歸之。

translations.text: Boyi and Shuqi were in Guzhu when they heard that the Western Earl was good at caring for the elderly, so why not go and join him?

sentences.zh: 太顛、閎夭、散宜生、鬻子、辛甲大夫之徒皆往歸之。

translations.text: Taidan, Hong Yao, San Yisheng, Yuzi, Xinjia, and other grand masters all went and joined him.

When Gongji died, his son Chang succeeded him; this was the Western Earl. The Western Earl was called King Wen; he followed the work of Houji and Gongliu, modeled himself on the methods of Gugong and Gongji, was devoted to benevolence, revered the old, and showed kindness to the young. He treated worthy men with courtesy, had no leisure to eat at midday while receiving scholars, and scholars for this reason came to him in great numbers. Boyi and Shuqi were in Guzhu when they heard that the Western Earl was good at caring for the elderly, so why not go and join him? Taidan, Hong Yao, San Yisheng, Yuzi, Xinjia, and other grand masters all went and joined him.

sentences.zh: 崇侯虎譖西伯於殷紂曰：「西伯積善累德，諸侯皆向之，將不利於帝。」

translations.text: Chonghou Hu slandered the Western Earl to King Zhou of Yin, saying: "The Western Earl accumulates good deeds and piles up virtue; all the feudal lords turn toward him, which will be disadvantageous to the Emperor."

sentences.zh: 帝紂乃囚西伯於羑里。

translations.text: Emperor Zhou thereupon imprisoned the Western Earl at Youli.

sentences.zh: 閎夭之徒患之。

translations.text: Hong Yao and his group were worried about this.

sentences.zh: 乃求有莘氏美女，驪戎之文馬，有熊九駟，他奇怪物，因殷嬖臣費仲而獻之紂。

translations.text: So they sought beautiful women from the Youxin clan, patterned horses from the Lirong, nine teams of four horses from Youxiong, and other rare and strange objects, and through Yin's favorite minister Fei Zhong presented them to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 紂大說，曰：「此一物足以釋西伯，況其多乎！」

translations.text: Zhou was greatly pleased and said: "Even one of these things would be enough to release the Western Earl, how much more so when there are many!"

sentences.zh: 乃赦西伯，賜之弓矢斧鉞，使西伯得征伐。

translations.text: So he pardoned the Western Earl, bestowed upon him bows, arrows, axes, and halberds, and allowed the Western Earl to conduct punitive expeditions.

sentences.zh: 曰：「譖西伯者，崇侯虎也。」

translations.text: He said: "The one who slandered the Western Earl was Chonghou Hu."

sentences.zh: 西伯乃獻洛西之地，以請紂去炮格之刑。

translations.text: The Western Earl then offered the land west of Luo, requesting that Zhou abolish the punishment of roasting on a bronze pillar.

sentences.zh: 紂許之。

translations.text: Zhou consented to this.

Chonghou Hu slandered the Western Earl to King Zhou of Yin, saying: "The Western Earl accumulates good deeds and piles up virtue; all the feudal lords turn toward him, which will be disadvantageous to the Emperor."  Emperor Zhou thereupon imprisoned the Western Earl at Youli. Hong Yao and his group were worried about this. So they sought beautiful women from the Youxin clan, patterned horses from the Lirong, nine teams of four horses from Youxiong, and other rare and strange objects, and through Yin's favorite minister Fei Zhong presented them to Zhou. Zhou was greatly pleased and said: "Even one of these things would be enough to release the Western Earl, how much more so when there are many!"  So he pardoned the Western Earl, bestowed upon him bows, arrows, axes, and halberds, and allowed the Western Earl to conduct punitive expeditions. He said: "The one who slandered the Western Earl was Chonghou Hu."  The Western Earl then offered the land west of Luo, requesting that Zhou abolish the punishment of roasting on a bronze pillar. Zhou consented to this.

sentences.zh: 西伯陰行善，諸侯皆來決平。

translations.text: The Western Earl secretly practiced goodness, and feudal lords all came to have him settle their disputes fairly.

sentences.zh: 於是虞、芮之人有獄不能決，乃如周。

translations.text: At this time, the people of Yu and Rui had a legal case they could not resolve, so they went to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 入界，耕者皆讓畔，民俗皆讓長。

translations.text: When they entered the border, farmers all yielded their field boundaries, and the common customs all deferred to elders.

sentences.zh: 虞、芮之人未見西伯，皆慚，相謂曰：「吾所爭，周人所恥，何往為，秖取辱耳。」

translations.text: The people of Yu and Rui, before even seeing the Western Earl, all felt ashamed and said to each other: "What we are disputing over is what the Zhou people consider shameful; why go there? We would only bring humiliation upon ourselves."

sentences.zh: 遂還，俱讓而去。

translations.text: So they returned, both yielding and departing.

sentences.zh: 諸侯聞之，曰「西伯蓋受命之君」。

translations.text: When the feudal lords heard of this, they said: "The Western Earl is indeed a ruler who has received the Mandate of Heaven."

The Western Earl secretly practiced goodness, and feudal lords all came to have him settle their disputes fairly. At this time, the people of Yu and Rui had a legal case they could not resolve, so they went to Zhou. When they entered the border, farmers all yielded their field boundaries, and the common customs all deferred to elders. The people of Yu and Rui, before even seeing the Western Earl, all felt ashamed and said to each other: "What we are disputing over is what the Zhou people consider shameful; why go there? We would only bring humiliation upon ourselves."  So they returned, both yielding and departing. When the feudal lords heard of this, they said: "The Western Earl is indeed a ruler who has received the Mandate of Heaven."

sentences.zh: 明年，伐犬戎。

translations.text: The following year, he attacked the Quanrong.

sentences.zh: 明年，伐密須。

translations.text: The following year, he attacked Mixu.

sentences.zh: 明年，敗耆國。

translations.text: The following year, he defeated the state of Qi.

sentences.zh: 殷之祖伊聞之，懼，以告帝紂。

translations.text: Zu Yi of Yin heard of this, was frightened, and reported it to Emperor Zhou.

sentences.zh: 紂曰：「不有天命乎？

translations.text: Zhou said: "Do I not possess the Mandate of Heaven?

sentences.zh: 是何能為！」

translations.text: What can he do!"

sentences.zh: 明年，伐邘。

translations.text: The following year, he attacked Yu.

sentences.zh: 明年，伐崇侯虎。

translations.text: The following year, he attacked Chonghou Hu.

sentences.zh: 而作豐邑，自岐下而徙都豐。

translations.text: He constructed the city of Feng and moved the capital from the foot of Mount Qi to Feng.

sentences.zh: 明年，西伯崩，太子發立，是為武王。

translations.text: The following year, the Western Earl died; Crown Prince Fa succeeded him; this was King Wu.

The following year, he attacked the Quanrong. The following year, he attacked Mixu. The following year, he defeated the state of Qi. Zu Yi of Yin heard of this, was frightened, and reported it to Emperor Zhou. Zhou said: "Do I not possess the Mandate of Heaven? What can he do!"  The following year, he attacked Yu. The following year, he attacked Chonghou Hu. He constructed the city of Feng and moved the capital from the foot of Mount Qi to Feng. The following year, the Western Earl died; Crown Prince Fa succeeded him; this was King Wu.

sentences.zh: 西伯蓋即位五十年。

translations.text: The Western Earl reigned for fifty years.

sentences.zh: 其囚羑里，蓋益易之八卦為六十四卦。

translations.text: During his imprisonment at Youli, he expanded the eight trigrams of the Yi to sixty-four hexagrams.

sentences.zh: 詩人道西伯，蓋受命之年稱王而斷虞芮之訟。

translations.text: The poets speak of the Western Earl claiming the title of king in the year he received the mandate and settling the dispute between Yu and Rui.

sentences.zh: 後十年而崩，謚為文王。

translations.text: Ten years later he died and was given the posthumous title King Wen.

sentences.zh: 改法度，制正朔矣。

translations.text: He changed the laws and regulations and established the calendar.

sentences.zh: 追尊古公為太王，公季為王季：蓋王瑞自太王興。

translations.text: He posthumously honored Gugong as King Tai and Gongji as King Ji; for the royal auspicious signs began to arise with King Tai.

The Western Earl reigned for fifty years. During his imprisonment at Youli, he expanded the eight trigrams of the Yi to sixty-four hexagrams. The poets speak of the Western Earl claiming the title of king in the year he received the mandate and settling the dispute between Yu and Rui. Ten years later he died and was given the posthumous title King Wen. He changed the laws and regulations and established the calendar. He posthumously honored Gugong as King Tai and Gongji as King Ji; for the royal auspicious signs began to arise with King Tai.

sentences.zh: 武王即位，太公望為師，周公旦為輔，召公、畢公之徒左右王，師修文王緒業。

translations.text: When King Wu ascended the throne, Taigong Wang served as Grand Preceptor, the Duke of Zhou Dan as assistant, and the Duke of Shao, Duke of Bi, and their followers flanked the king; all continued King Wen's unfinished work.

When King Wu ascended the throne, Taigong Wang served as Grand Preceptor, the Duke of Zhou Dan as assistant, and the Duke of Shao, Duke of Bi, and their followers flanked the king; all continued King Wen's unfinished work.

sentences.zh: 九年，武王上祭于畢。

translations.text: In the ninth year, King Wu went to offer sacrifices at Bi.

sentences.zh: 東觀兵，至于盟津。

translations.text: He went east to review his troops, reaching Mengjin.

sentences.zh: 為文王木主，載以車，中軍。

translations.text: He made a wooden spirit tablet for King Wen, carried it in a chariot in the center army.

sentences.zh: 武王自稱太子發，言奉文王以伐，不敢自專。

translations.text: King Wu called himself Crown Prince Fa, saying he was conducting the campaign in service to King Wen and dared not act on his own authority.

sentences.zh: 乃告司馬、司徒、司空、諸節：「齊栗，信哉！

translations.text: He then informed the Minister of War, Minister of Education, Minister of Works, and all the officers: "Be reverent and solemn, truly!

In the ninth year, King Wu went to offer sacrifices at Bi. He went east to review his troops, reaching Mengjin. He made a wooden spirit tablet for King Wen, carried it in a chariot in the center army. King Wu called himself Crown Prince Fa, saying he was conducting the campaign in service to King Wen and dared not act on his own authority. He then informed the Minister of War, Minister of Education, Minister of Works, and all the officers: "Be reverent and solemn, truly! I am without wisdom, but because my ancestors had virtuous ministers, I, an unworthy son, have received their past achievements; I will fully establish rewards and punishments to determine merit."  Thereupon he raised the army. The Grand Preceptor Shangfu proclaimed: "Assemble all your masses, with your boats and oars; those who arrive late will be beheaded." On the jiazi day of the second month at dawn, King Wu arrived in the morning at Muye in the outskirts of Shang and made an oath. King Wu held a yellow battle-axe in his left hand and a white yak-tail banner in his right, using it to signal. He said: "You have come far, people of the western land!"  King Wu said: "Alas! My state lords, Ministers of Education, War, and Works, subordinate officers, military leaders, commanders of a thousand, commanders of a hundred, and people of Yong, Shu, Qiang, Mao, Wei, Lu, Peng, and Pu: raise your spears, hold your shields, stand with your lances; I shall make an oath."  The king said: "The ancients had a saying: 'A hen does not herald the dawn. When a hen heralds the dawn, it means only the ruin of the family.' Now King Zhou of Yin heeds only a woman's words, has abandoned his ancestors' sacrifices without response, in his confusion has abandoned his state and family, neglects his uncles and brothers and does not employ them, but instead honors and elevates criminals and fugitives from all quarters, trusts and employs them, causing them to tyrannize the people and commit treachery in the state of Shang. Now I, Fa, respectfully carry out Heaven's punishment. In today's affair, take no more than six or seven steps, then stop and align; exert yourselves, gentlemen! Make no more than four, five, six, or seven strokes, then stop and align; exert yourselves, gentlemen! Be valiant and mighty, like tigers, like bears, like jackals, like fierce beasts in the outskirts of Shang; do not resist those who flee, so that they may serve the western land; exert yourselves, gentlemen! If you do not exert yourselves, you yourselves will be punished."  After the oath, the feudal lords' assembled armies had four thousand chariots, and they arrayed their forces at Muye.

sentences.zh: 我未定天保，何暇寐！」

sentences.zh: 王曰：「定天保，依天室，悉求夫惡，貶從殷王受。

translations.text: The king said: "To secure Heaven's protection and rely on Heaven's dwelling, we must thoroughly search for evils and demote followers of King Shou of Yin.

sentences.zh: 日夜勞來定我西土，我維顯服，及德方明。

translations.text: Day and night I labor to stabilize our western land; I only manifestly submit, and virtue is just becoming clear.

sentences.zh: 自洛汭延于伊汭，居易毋固，其有夏之居。

translations.text: From the bend of the Luo extending to the bend of the Yi, dwelling in ease without rigidity, like the dwelling of the Xia.

sentences.zh: 我南望三涂，北望嶽鄙，顧詹有河，粵詹雒、伊，毋遠天室。」

translations.text: To the south I gaze at Santu, to the north at Yuebi; looking back I observe the River, and gazing I see the Luo and Yi; not far from Heaven's dwelling."

sentences.zh: 營周居于雒邑而後去。

translations.text: He planned a Zhou residence at Luoyi and then departed.

sentences.zh: 縱馬於華山之陽，放牛於桃林之虛；

translations.text: He released the horses on the southern slopes of Mount Hua and set the oxen free in the wilderness of Taolin.

sentences.zh: 偃干戈，振兵釋旅：示天下不復用也。

translations.text: He laid down shields and spears, stood down the troops and dismissed the armies, showing all under Heaven that they would not be used again.

King Wu summoned the lords of the nine provinces, ascended the hill of Bin, and gazed at the city of Shang. When King Wu returned to Zhou, he could not sleep all night. The Duke of Zhou Dan came to the king and said: "Why can you not sleep?"  The king said: "I tell you: Heaven has not favored Yin; from before I was born until now, sixty years have passed; deer roam in the pasturelands, and wild geese fill the fields. Heaven has not accepted Yin, and now there is accomplishment. When Heaven established Yin, it elevated three hundred sixty renowned men; they were neither illustrious nor were they completely destroyed, up to now. I have not yet secured Heaven's protection; how can I have leisure to sleep!"  The king said: "To secure Heaven's protection and rely on Heaven's dwelling, we must thoroughly search for evils and demote followers of King Shou of Yin. Day and night I labor to stabilize our western land; I only manifestly submit, and virtue is just becoming clear. From the bend of the Luo extending to the bend of the Yi, dwelling in ease without rigidity, like the dwelling of the Xia. To the south I gaze at Santu, to the north at Yuebi; looking back I observe the River, and gazing I see the Luo and Yi; not far from Heaven's dwelling."  He planned a Zhou residence at Luoyi and then departed. He released the horses on the southern slopes of Mount Hua and set the oxen free in the wilderness of Taolin. He laid down shields and spears, stood down the troops and dismissed the armies, showing all under Heaven that they would not be used again.

sentences.zh: 武王已克殷，後二年，問箕子殷所以亡。

translations.text: Two years after King Wu had conquered Yin, he asked Jizi about the reasons for Yin's downfall.

sentences.zh: 箕子不忍言殷惡，以存亡國宜告。

translations.text: Jizi could not bear to speak of Yin's evils, so he informed him about what was proper for preserving or destroying a state.

sentences.zh: 武王亦醜，故問以天道。

translations.text: King Wu also considered it shameful, so he asked about the Way of Heaven.

Two years after King Wu had conquered Yin, he asked Jizi about the reasons for Yin's downfall. Jizi could not bear to speak of Yin's evils, so he informed him about what was proper for preserving or destroying a state. King Wu also considered it shameful, so he asked about the Way of Heaven.

sentences.zh: 武王病。

translations.text: King Wu fell ill.

sentences.zh: 天下未集，群公懼，穆卜，周公乃祓齋，自為質，欲代武王，武王有瘳。

translations.text: All under Heaven was not yet unified, and the dukes were afraid; they performed divination; the Duke of Zhou then performed purification and fasting, offered himself as a pledge, wishing to take King Wu's place, and King Wu recovered.

sentences.zh: 後而崩，太子誦代立，是為成王。

translations.text: Later he died, and Crown Prince Song succeeded him; this was King Cheng.

King Wu fell ill. All under Heaven was not yet unified, and the dukes were afraid; they performed divination; the Duke of Zhou then performed purification and fasting, offered himself as a pledge, wishing to take King Wu's place, and King Wu recovered. Later he died, and Crown Prince Song succeeded him; this was King Cheng.

sentences.zh: 成王少，周初定天下，周公恐諸侯畔周，公乃攝行政當國。

translations.text: King Cheng was young, and Zhou had just stabilized all under Heaven; the Duke of Zhou feared that the feudal lords would rebel against Zhou, so the Duke acted as regent and governed the state.

sentences.zh: 管叔、蔡叔群弟疑周公，與武庚作亂，畔周。

translations.text: Guan Shu, Cai Shu, and their brothers suspected the Duke of Zhou, joined with Wugeng to create disorder, and rebelled against Zhou.

sentences.zh: 周公奉成王命，伐誅武庚、管叔，放蔡叔。

translations.text: The Duke of Zhou, following King Cheng's command, attacked and executed Wugeng and Guan Shu, and exiled Cai Shu.

sentences.zh: 以微子開代殷後，國於宋。

translations.text: He had Weizi Kai succeed as heir of Yin and established him in the state at Song.

sentences.zh: 頗收殷餘民，以封武王少弟封為衛康叔。

translations.text: He gathered many of the remaining people of Yin and enfeoffed King Wu's younger brother Feng as Kang Shu of Wei.

sentences.zh: 晉唐叔得嘉穀，獻之成王，成王以歸周公于兵所。

translations.text: Tang Shu of Jin obtained excellent grain and presented it to King Cheng; King Cheng sent it to the Duke of Zhou at the military camp.

sentences.zh: 周公受禾東土，魯天子之命。

translations.text: The Duke of Zhou received the grain in the eastern land and proclaimed the Son of Heaven's command in Lu.

sentences.zh: 初，管、蔡畔周，周公討之，三年而畢定，故初作大誥，次作微子之命，次歸禾，次嘉禾，次康誥、酒誥、梓材，其事在周公之篇。

translations.text: Initially, when Guan and Cai rebelled against Zhou, the Duke of Zhou campaigned against them and completely pacified them in three years; therefore he first composed the "Great Announcement," next composed "The Mandate of Weizi," next "Returning the Grain," next "Excellent Grain," next "The Announcement to Kang," "The Announcement on Wine," and "The Catalpa Wood"; these matters are in the chapters on the Duke of Zhou.

sentences.zh: 周公行政七年，成王長，周公反政成王，北面就群臣之位。

translations.text: After the Duke of Zhou governed for seven years, King Cheng matured, and the Duke of Zhou returned the government to King Cheng, facing north and taking his place among the ministers.

King Cheng was young, and Zhou had just stabilized all under Heaven; the Duke of Zhou feared that the feudal lords would rebel against Zhou, so the Duke acted as regent and governed the state. Guan Shu, Cai Shu, and their brothers suspected the Duke of Zhou, joined with Wugeng to create disorder, and rebelled against Zhou. The Duke of Zhou, following King Cheng's command, attacked and executed Wugeng and Guan Shu, and exiled Cai Shu. He had Weizi Kai succeed as heir of Yin and established him in the state at Song. He gathered many of the remaining people of Yin and enfeoffed King Wu's younger brother Feng as Kang Shu of Wei. Tang Shu of Jin obtained excellent grain and presented it to King Cheng; King Cheng sent it to the Duke of Zhou at the military camp. The Duke of Zhou received the grain in the eastern land and proclaimed the Son of Heaven's command in Lu. Initially, when Guan and Cai rebelled against Zhou, the Duke of Zhou campaigned against them and completely pacified them in three years; therefore he first composed the "Great Announcement," next composed "The Mandate of Weizi," next "Returning the Grain," next "Excellent Grain," next "The Announcement to Kang," "The Announcement on Wine," and "The Catalpa Wood"; these matters are in the chapters on the Duke of Zhou. After the Duke of Zhou governed for seven years, King Cheng matured, and the Duke of Zhou returned the government to King Cheng, facing north and taking his place among the ministers.

sentences.zh: 成王在豐，使召公復營洛邑，如武王之意。

translations.text: While King Cheng was at Feng, he had the Duke of Shao again plan the building of Luoyi, according to King Wu's intention.

sentences.zh: 周公復卜申視，卒營筑，居九鼎焉。

translations.text: The Duke of Zhou again performed divination and inspection, completed the construction, and placed the Nine Tripods there.

sentences.zh: 曰：「此天下之中，四方入貢道里均。」

translations.text: He said: "This is the center of all under Heaven; the distances for tribute from the four directions are equal."

sentences.zh: 作召誥、洛誥。

translations.text: He composed the "Announcement of Shao" and "Announcement of Luo."

sentences.zh: 成王既遷殷遺民，周公以王命告，作多士、無佚。

translations.text: After King Cheng relocated the remaining people of Yin, the Duke of Zhou made proclamations by the king's command and composed "Many Officials" and "Against Idleness."

sentences.zh: 召公為保，周公為師，東伐淮夷，殘奄，遷其君薄泵。

translations.text: The Duke of Shao served as Protector, the Duke of Zhou as Preceptor; they attacked the Huaiyi to the east, destroyed Yan, and relocated its lord to Bopou.

sentences.zh: 成王自奄歸，在宗周，作多方。

translations.text: King Cheng returned from Yan, was at Zongzhou, and composed "Many Regions."

sentences.zh: 既絀殷命，襲淮夷，歸在豐，作周官。

translations.text: After rejecting Yin's mandate, attacking the Huaiyi, and returning to Feng, he composed "Officials of Zhou."

sentences.zh: 興正禮樂，度制於是改，而民和睦，頌聲興。

translations.text: He promoted proper rituals and music; regulations and systems were reformed accordingly, and the people became harmonious and peaceful, and songs of praise arose.

sentences.zh: 成王既伐東夷，息慎來賀，王賜榮伯作賄息慎之命。

translations.text: After King Cheng attacked the Eastern Yi, the Xishen came to congratulate him; the king ordered Rong Bo to give gifts and composed "The Command Regarding Gifts to the Xishen."

While King Cheng was at Feng, he had the Duke of Shao again plan the building of Luoyi, according to King Wu's intention. The Duke of Zhou again performed divination and inspection, completed the construction, and placed the Nine Tripods there. He said: "This is the center of all under Heaven; the distances for tribute from the four directions are equal."  He composed the "Announcement of Shao" and "Announcement of Luo." After King Cheng relocated the remaining people of Yin, the Duke of Zhou made proclamations by the king's command and composed "Many Officials" and "Against Idleness." The Duke of Shao served as Protector, the Duke of Zhou as Preceptor; they attacked the Huaiyi to the east, destroyed Yan, and relocated its lord to Bopou. King Cheng returned from Yan, was at Zongzhou, and composed "Many Regions." After rejecting Yin's mandate, attacking the Huaiyi, and returning to Feng, he composed "Officials of Zhou." He promoted proper rituals and music; regulations and systems were reformed accordingly, and the people became harmonious and peaceful, and songs of praise arose. After King Cheng attacked the Eastern Yi, the Xishen came to congratulate him; the king ordered Rong Bo to give gifts and composed "The Command Regarding Gifts to the Xishen."

sentences.zh: 成王將崩，懼太子釗之不任，乃命召公、畢公率諸侯以相太子而立之。

translations.text: When King Cheng was about to die, he feared that Crown Prince Zhao would not be adequate, so he ordered the Duke of Shao and the Duke of Bi to lead the feudal lords to assist the crown prince and establish him.

sentences.zh: 成王既崩，二公率諸侯，以太子釗見於先王廟，申告以文王、武王之所以為王業之不易，務在節儉，毋多欲，以篤信臨之，作顧命。

translations.text: After King Cheng died, the two dukes led the feudal lords and presented Crown Prince Zhao at the temple of the former kings, earnestly informing him of how King Wen and King Wu's royal achievements were not easily attained, that one must be frugal, not have many desires, and govern with sincere trust; they composed "The Testamentary Charge."

sentences.zh: 太子釗遂立，是為康王。

translations.text: Crown Prince Zhao then succeeded; this was King Kang.

sentences.zh: 康王即位，遍告諸侯，宣告以文武之業以申之，作《康誥》。

translations.text: When King Kang ascended the throne, he informed all the feudal lords, proclaimed King Wen and King Wu's achievements to emphasize them, and composed "The Announcement of Kang."

sentences.zh: 故成康之際，天下安寧，刑錯四十餘年不用。

translations.text: Therefore during the reigns of King Cheng and King Kang, all under Heaven was peaceful and tranquil, and criminal punishments were set aside for more than forty years without use.

sentences.zh: 康王命作策畢公分居里，成周郊，作《畢命》。

translations.text: King Kang ordered the creation of a document for the Duke of Bi to allocate residences in the suburbs of Chengzhou and composed "The Command to Bi."

King Kang ordered the creation of a document for the Duke of Bi to allocate residences in the suburbs of Chengzhou and composed "The Command to Bi."

sentences.zh: 康王卒，子昭王瑕立。

translations.text: When King Kang died, his son King Zhao Xia succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 昭王之時，王道微缺。

translations.text: In King Zhao's time, the kingly way slightly declined.

sentences.zh: 昭王南巡狩不返，卒於江上。

translations.text: King Zhao went on a southern inspection tour and did not return; he died on the Jiang River.

sentences.zh: 其卒不赴告，諱之也。

translations.text: His death was not reported; it was kept secret.

sentences.zh: 立昭王子滿，是為穆王。

translations.text: King Zhao's son Man was installed; this was King Mu.

sentences.zh: 穆王即位，春秋已五十矣。

translations.text: When King Mu ascended the throne, he was already fifty years old.

sentences.zh: 王道衰微，穆王閔文武之道缺，乃命伯臩申誡太仆國之政，作臩命。

translations.text: The kingly way was declining; King Mu, saddened that the way of King Wen and King Wu was lacking, ordered Bo Yong to earnestly admonish the Grand Coachman about the state's government and composed "The Command to Yong."

sentences.zh: 復寧。

translations.text: Tranquility was restored.

When King Kang died, his son King Zhao Xia succeeded him. In King Zhao's time, the kingly way slightly declined. King Zhao went on a southern inspection tour and did not return; he died on the Jiang River. His death was not reported; it was kept secret. King Zhao's son Man was installed; this was King Mu. When King Mu ascended the throne, he was already fifty years old. The kingly way was declining; King Mu, saddened that the way of King Wen and King Wu was lacking, ordered Bo Yong to earnestly admonish the Grand Coachman about the state's government and composed "The Command to Yong." Tranquility was restored.

translations.text: When King Mu was about to attack the Quanrong, Jigong Moufu remonstrated, saying: "You cannot.

sentences.zh: 先王燿德不觀兵。

translations.text: The former kings displayed virtue, not military force.

sentences.zh: 夫兵戢而時動，動則威，觀則玩，玩則無震。

translations.text: Military force should be restrained and only used at appropriate times; when used it inspires awe, when displayed it becomes familiar, and when familiar it loses its power to intimidate.

sentences.zh: 是故周文公之頌曰：『載戢干戈，載櫜弓矢，我求懿德，肆于時夏，允王保之。』

translations.text: Therefore the ode of Zhou Wengong says: 'We put away shields and spears, we sheathe bows and arrows, I seek beautiful virtue, spread it in the great Xia, and the king truly preserves it.'

sentences.zh: 先王之於民也，茂正其德而厚其性，阜其財求而利其器用，明利害之鄉，以文修之，使之務利而辟害，懷德而畏威，故能保世以滋大。

translations.text: The former kings, in dealing with the people, cultivated and rectified their virtue and enriched their nature, multiplied their wealth and made their implements useful, clarified what was beneficial and harmful, cultivated them with civil culture, made them pursue benefit and avoid harm, cherish virtue and fear authority; therefore they were able to preserve their reigns and grow ever greater.

sentences.zh: 昔我先王世后稷以服事虞、夏。

translations.text: In former times our ancestors for generations, from Houji onward, served Yu and Xia.

sentences.zh: 及夏之衰也，棄稷不務，我先王不窋用失其官，而自竄於戎狄之閒。

translations.text: When Xia declined, they abandoned the office of Ji and did not attend to it; our ancestor Buzhu thus lost his office and fled to hide among the Rong and Di.

sentences.zh: 不敢怠業，時序其德，遵修其緒，修其訓典，朝夕恪勤，守以敦篤，奉以忠信。

translations.text: Not daring to neglect his duties, he continually cultivated his virtue, followed and maintained his heritage, cultivated his teachings and laws, morning and evening was respectfully diligent, guarded with sincerity and loyalty, and served with faithful devotion.

sentences.zh: 奕世載德，不忝前人。

translations.text: Through successive generations they carried on virtue, not shaming their predecessors.

sentences.zh: 至于文王、武王，昭前之光明而加之以慈和，事神保民，無不欣喜。

translations.text: When it came to King Wen and King Wu, they illuminated the brilliance of their predecessors and added to it compassion and harmony, served the spirits and protected the people, and all were joyful.

sentences.zh: 商王帝辛大惡于民，庶民不忍，訢載武王，以致戎于商牧。

translations.text: King Di Xin of Shang greatly wronged the people; the common people could not bear it and joyfully supported King Wu, thereby bringing the army to the fields of Shang.

sentences.zh: 是故先王非務武也，勸恤民隱而除其害也。

translations.text: Therefore the former kings did not pursue military affairs, but encouraged concern for the people's suffering and eliminated their harm.

sentences.zh: 夫先王之制，邦內甸服，邦外侯服，侯衛賓服，夷蠻要服，戎翟荒服。

translations.text: The former kings' system was: within the state was the dian service zone, outside the state was the hou service zone, beyond the hou was the bin service zone, the Yi and Man were the yao service zone, and the Rong and Di were the huang service zone.

sentences.zh: 甸服者祭，侯服者祀，賓服者享，要服者貢，荒服者王。

translations.text: The dian zone performed sacrifices, the hou zone performed ancestral offerings, the bin zone presented tributes, the yao zone brought contributions, and the huang zone acknowledged the king.

sentences.zh: 日祭，月祀，時享，歲貢，終王。

translations.text: Daily sacrifices, monthly offerings, seasonal presentations, yearly contributions, and lifelong acknowledgment of the king.

sentences.zh: 先王之順祀也，有不祭則修意，有不祀則修言，有不享則修文，有不貢則修名，有不王則修德，序成而有不至則修刑。

translations.text: In the former kings' proper ritual system, if there were no sacrifices they cultivated goodwill, if no offerings they cultivated speech, if no presentations they cultivated civil culture, if no contributions they cultivated reputation, if no acknowledgment of the king they cultivated virtue, and only if the order was established and some still did not come did they apply punishments.

sentences.zh: 於是有刑不祭，伐不祀，征不享，讓不貢，告不王。

translations.text: Thus there was punishment for not sacrificing, attack for not offering, expedition for not presenting, admonishment for not contributing, and proclamation for not acknowledging the king.

sentences.zh: 於是有刑罰之辟，有攻伐之兵，有征討之備，有威讓之命，有文告之辭。

translations.text: Thus there were punishments and penalties, there were attacking and punitive troops, there were expeditionary preparations, there were threatening and yielding commands, there were civil announcements and statements.

sentences.zh: 布令陳辭而有不至，則增修於德，無勤民於遠。

translations.text: If after issuing orders and making proclamations some still did not come, they would further cultivate virtue and not trouble the people with distant campaigns.

sentences.zh: 是以近無不聽，遠無不服。

translations.text: Therefore those near all obeyed, and those far all submitted.

sentences.zh: 今自大畢、伯士之終也，犬戎氏以其職來王，天子曰『予必以不享征之，且觀之兵』，無乃廢先王之訓，而王幾頓乎？

translations.text: Now since the end of Dabi and Boshi, the Quanrong have come to acknowledge the king with their duties, yet the Son of Heaven says 'I must attack them for not presenting tributes, and display military force to them'; would this not abandon the teachings of the former kings and bring the king near to ruin?

sentences.zh: 吾聞犬戎樹敦，率舊德而守終純固，其有以御我矣。」

translations.text: I have heard that the Quanrong are sincere and honest, follow ancient virtue, and remain purely steadfast; they will have the means to resist us."

sentences.zh: 王遂征之，得四白狼四白鹿以歸。

translations.text: The king nevertheless attacked them, obtained four white wolves and four white deer, and returned.

sentences.zh: 自是荒服者不至。

translations.text: From this time on, those in the huang service zone did not come.

Therefore the ode of Zhou Wengong says: 'We put away shields and spears, we sheathe bows and arrows, I seek beautiful virtue, spread it in the great Xia, and the king truly preserves it.' In former times our ancestors for generations, from Houji onward, served Yu and Xia. When Xia declined, they abandoned the office of Ji and did not attend to it; our ancestor Buzhu thus lost his office and fled to hide among the Rong and Di. Not daring to neglect his duties, he continually cultivated his virtue, followed and maintained his heritage, cultivated his teachings and laws, morning and evening was respectfully diligent, guarded with sincerity and loyalty, and served with faithful devotion. Through successive generations they carried on virtue, not shaming their predecessors. When it came to King Wen and King Wu, they illuminated the brilliance of their predecessors and added to it compassion and harmony, served the spirits and protected the people, and all were joyful. King Di Xin of Shang greatly wronged the people; the common people could not bear it and joyfully supported King Wu, thereby bringing the army to the fields of Shang. Therefore the former kings did not pursue military affairs, but encouraged concern for the people's suffering and eliminated their harm. The former kings' system was: within the state was the dian service zone, outside the state was the hou service zone, beyond the hou was the bin service zone, the Yi and Man were the yao service zone, and the Rong and Di were the huang service zone. The dian zone performed sacrifices, the hou zone performed ancestral offerings, the bin zone presented tributes, the yao zone brought contributions, and the huang zone acknowledged the king. Thus there were punishments and penalties, there were attacking and punitive troops, there were expeditionary preparations, there were threatening and yielding commands, there were civil announcements and statements. I have heard that the Quanrong are sincere and honest, follow ancient virtue, and remain purely steadfast; they will have the means to resist us."  The king nevertheless attacked them, obtained four white wolves and four white deer, and returned. From this time on, those in the huang service zone did not come.

sentences.zh: 諸侯有不睦者，甫侯言於王，作修刑辟。

translations.text: When there were feudal lords who were not harmonious, Fu Hou spoke to the king and composed reforms to the criminal laws.

sentences.zh: 王曰：「吁，來！

translations.text: The king said: "Ah, come!

sentences.zh: 有國有土，告汝祥刑。

translations.text: You who have states and territories, I inform you of auspicious punishments.

sentences.zh: 在今爾安百姓，何擇非其人，何敬非其刑，何居非其宜與？

translations.text: Now as you pacify the hundred clans, how can you choose the wrong people, how can you not respect proper punishments, how can you not dwell in what is appropriate?

sentences.zh: 兩造具備，師聽五辭。

translations.text: When both parties are present, the judge hears the five types of testimony.

sentences.zh: 五辭簡信，正於五刑。

translations.text: If the five testimonies are clear and trustworthy, apply the five punishments correctly.

sentences.zh: 五刑不簡，正於五罰。

translations.text: If the five punishments are not clear, apply the five fines correctly.

sentences.zh: 五罰不服，正於五過。

translations.text: If the five fines are not accepted, examine the five types of errors correctly.

sentences.zh: 五過之疵，官獄內獄，閱實其罪，惟鈞其過。

translations.text: Regarding the defects of the five errors, in official prisons and inner prisons, examine their crimes truthfully, only weighing their errors equally.

sentences.zh: 五刑之疑有赦，五罰之疑有赦，其審克之。

translations.text: When the five punishments are doubtful grant pardon, when the five fines are doubtful grant pardon; examine and decide them carefully.

sentences.zh: 簡信有眾，惟訊有稽。

translations.text: Be clear and trustworthy with the multitude; only interrogate when there is something to investigate.

sentences.zh: 無簡不疑，共嚴天威。

translations.text: Do not simplify what is doubtful; together uphold the stern majesty of Heaven.

sentences.zh: 黥辟疑赦，其罰百率，閱實其罪。

translations.text: For tattooing punishment when doubtful grant pardon; the fine is one hundred units; examine the crime truthfully.

sentences.zh: 劓辟疑赦，其罰倍灑，閱實其罪。

translations.text: For nose-cutting punishment when doubtful grant pardon; the fine is double that amount; examine the crime truthfully.

sentences.zh: 臏辟疑赦，其罰倍差，閱實其罪。

translations.text: For foot-amputation punishment when doubtful grant pardon; the fine is double the difference; examine the crime truthfully.

sentences.zh: 宮辟疑赦，其罰五百率，閱實其罪。

translations.text: For castration punishment when doubtful grant pardon; the fine is five hundred units; examine the crime truthfully.

sentences.zh: 大辟疑赦，其罰千率，閱實其罪。

translations.text: For capital punishment when doubtful grant pardon; the fine is one thousand units; examine the crime truthfully.

sentences.zh: 墨罰之屬千，劓罰之屬千，臏罰之屬五百，宮罰之屬三百，大辟之罰其屬二百：五刑之屬三千。」

translations.text: The categories under tattooing punishment are one thousand, the categories under nose-cutting punishment are one thousand, the categories under foot-amputation punishment are five hundred, the categories under castration punishment are three hundred, the categories under capital punishment are two hundred: the five punishments have three thousand categories in all."
