sentences.zh: 穆王立五十五年，崩，子共王繄扈立。

translations.text: King Mu reigned for fifty-five years and died; his son King Gong Yihu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 共王游於涇上，密康公從，有三女奔之。

translations.text: King Gong was traveling on the Jing River; Mi Kanggong accompanied him, and three women came to him.

sentences.zh: 其母曰：「必致之王。

translations.text: Their mother said: "You must present them to the king.

sentences.zh: 夫獸三為群，人三為眾，女三為粲。

translations.text: Three beasts make a herd, three men make a crowd, three women make brilliance.

sentences.zh: 王田不取群，公行不下眾，王御不參一族。

translations.text: When the king hunts he does not take a whole herd, when a duke travels he does not stay with a crowd, when the king takes concubines he does not take three from one clan.

sentences.zh: 夫粲，美之物也。

translations.text: Now brilliance is a beautiful thing.

sentences.zh: 眾以美物歸女，而何德以堪之？

translations.text: The crowd brings beautiful things to you, but what virtue do you have to be worthy of them?

sentences.zh: 王猶不堪，況爾之小醜乎！

translations.text: Even the king is not worthy of them; how much less you, a minor vassal!

sentences.zh: 小醜備物，終必亡。」

translations.text: When minor vassals possess such things, they will surely perish in the end."

sentences.zh: 康公不獻，一年，共王滅密。

translations.text: Kanggong did not present them; a year later, King Gong destroyed Mi.

sentences.zh: 共王崩，子懿王艱立。

translations.text: When King Gong died, his son King Yi Jian succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 懿王之時，王室遂衰，詩人作刺。

translations.text: In King Yi's time, the royal house declined further, and poets composed satires.

King Mu reigned for fifty-five years and died; his son King Gong Yihu succeeded him. King Gong was traveling on the Jing River; Mi Kanggong accompanied him, and three women came to him. Their mother said: "You must present them to the king. Three beasts make a herd, three men make a crowd, three women make brilliance. When the king hunts he does not take a whole herd, when a duke travels he does not stay with a crowd, when the king takes concubines he does not take three from one clan. Now brilliance is a beautiful thing. The crowd brings beautiful things to you, but what virtue do you have to be worthy of them? Even the king is not worthy of them; how much less you, a minor vassal! When minor vassals possess such things, they will surely perish in the end."  Kanggong did not present them; a year later, King Gong destroyed Mi. When King Gong died, his son King Yi Jian succeeded him. In King Yi's time, the royal house declined further, and poets composed satires.

sentences.zh: 懿王崩，共王弟辟方立，是為孝王。

translations.text: When King Yi died, King Gong's younger brother Pifang succeeded him; this was King Xiao.

sentences.zh: 孝王崩，諸侯復立懿王太子燮，是為夷王。

translations.text: When King Xiao died, the feudal lords reinstalled King Yi's crown prince Xie; this was King Yi.
When King Yi died, King Gong's younger brother Pifang succeeded him; this was King Xiao. When King Xiao died, the feudal lords reinstalled King Yi's crown prince Xie; this was King Yi.

sentences.zh: 夷王崩，子厲王胡立。

translations.text: When King Yi died, his son King Li Hu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 厲王即位三十年，好利，近榮夷公。

translations.text: In the thirtieth year of King Li's reign, he loved profit and became close to Rong Yigong.

sentences.zh: 大夫芮良夫諫厲王曰：「王室其將卑乎？

translations.text: Grand Master Rui Liangfu remonstrated with King Li, saying: "Will the royal house be brought low?

sentences.zh: 夫榮公好專利而不知大難。

translations.text: Now Rong Gong loves to monopolize profit and does not recognize the great danger.

sentences.zh: 夫利，百物之所生也，天地之所載也，而有專之，其害多矣。

translations.text: Now profit is what the hundred things arise from, what heaven and earth sustain; to monopolize it brings much harm.

sentences.zh: 天地百物皆將取焉，何可專也？

translations.text: All things of heaven and earth will seek to take from it; how can it be monopolized?

sentences.zh: 所怒甚多，不備大難。

translations.text: Those angered will be very many, and he is not prepared for great calamity.

sentences.zh: 以是教王，王其能久乎？

translations.text: To teach the king with this—can the king last long?

sentences.zh: 夫王人者，將導利而布之上下者也。

translations.text: One who rules over people should guide profit and distribute it to high and low.

sentences.zh: 使神人百物無不得極，猶日怵惕懼怨之來也。

translations.text: Enabling spirits, people, and all things to attain their utmost, yet still daily being anxious and fearful that resentment will come.

sentences.zh: 故《頌》曰『思文后稷，克配彼天，立我蒸民，莫匪爾極』。

translations.text: Therefore the Odes say: 'Admirable Houji, able to match Heaven, established our multitudes, none failed to reach their utmost.'

sentences.zh: 大雅曰『陳錫載周』。

translations.text: The Greater Odes say: 'Displayed gifts sustained Zhou.'

sentences.zh: 是不布利而懼難乎，故能載周以至于今。

translations.text: Thus they distributed profit while fearing calamity, therefore they were able to sustain Zhou up to now.

sentences.zh: 今王學專利，其可乎？

translations.text: Now the king learns to monopolize profit; is this acceptable?

sentences.zh: 匹夫專利，猶謂之盜，王而行之，其歸鮮矣。

translations.text: When a common man monopolizes profit, he is still called a thief; if the king does this, few will turn to him.

sentences.zh: 榮公若用，周必敗也。」

translations.text: If Rong Gong is employed, Zhou will surely be defeated."

sentences.zh: 厲王不聽，卒以榮公為卿士，用事。

translations.text: King Li did not listen and in the end made Rong Gong a minister and put him in charge of affairs.

When King Yi died, his son King Li Hu succeeded him. In the thirtieth year of King Li's reign, he loved profit and became close to Rong Yigong. Grand Master Rui Liangfu remonstrated with King Li, saying: "Will the royal house be brought low? Now Rong Gong loves to monopolize profit and does not recognize the great danger. Now profit is what the hundred things arise from, what heaven and earth sustain; to monopolize it brings much harm. All things of heaven and earth will seek to take from it; how can it be monopolized? Those angered will be very many, and he is not prepared for great calamity. To teach the king with this—can the king last long? One who rules over people should guide profit and distribute it to high and low. Enabling spirits, people, and all things to attain their utmost, yet still daily being anxious and fearful that resentment will come. Therefore the Odes say: 'Admirable Houji, able to match Heaven, established our multitudes, none failed to reach their utmost.' The Greater Odes say: 'Displayed gifts sustained Zhou.' Thus they distributed profit while fearing calamity, therefore they were able to sustain Zhou up to now. Now the king learns to monopolize profit; is this acceptable? When a common man monopolizes profit, he is still called a thief; if the king does this, few will turn to him. If Rong Gong is employed, Zhou will surely be defeated."  King Li did not listen and in the end made Rong Gong a minister and put him in charge of affairs.

sentences.zh: 王行暴虐侈傲，國人謗王。

translations.text: The king acted with cruel tyranny and extravagant arrogance, and the people of the state slandered the king.

sentences.zh: 召公諫曰：「民不堪命矣。」

translations.text: The Duke of Shao remonstrated, saying: "The people cannot bear these orders."

sentences.zh: 王怒，得衛巫，使監謗者，以告則殺之。

translations.text: The king became angry, obtained a shaman from Wei, and had him spy on those who slandered; if they reported, he would kill them.

sentences.zh: 其謗鮮矣，諸侯不朝。

translations.text: Slander decreased, but the feudal lords did not come to court.

sentences.zh: 三十四年，王益嚴，國人莫敢言，道路以目。

translations.text: In the thirty-fourth year, the king became even stricter; the people of the state dared not speak and communicated on the roads only with their eyes.

sentences.zh: 厲王喜，告召公曰：「吾能弭謗矣，乃不敢言。」

translations.text: King Li was pleased and told the Duke of Shao: "I can stop slander now; they dare not speak."

sentences.zh: 召公曰：「是鄣之也。

translations.text: The Duke of Shao said: "This is blocking them.

sentences.zh: 防民之口，甚於防水。

translations.text: Blocking the mouths of the people is worse than blocking water.

sentences.zh: 水壅而潰，傷人必多，民亦如之。

translations.text: When water is dammed up and bursts through, it will surely harm many people; the people are also like this.

sentences.zh: 是故為水者決之使導，為民者宣之使言。

translations.text: Therefore those who manage water open channels to guide it, and those who govern people allow them to speak freely.

sentences.zh: 故天子聽政，使公卿至於列士獻詩，瞽獻曲，史獻書，師箴，瞍賦，矇誦，百工諫，庶人傳語，近臣盡規，親戚補察，瞽史教誨，耆艾修之，而後王斟酌焉，是以事行而不悖。

translations.text: Therefore when the Son of Heaven attended to government, he had dukes and ministers down to ranked officials present poems, blind musicians present songs, scribes present writings, preceptors offer admonitions, blind men recite, sightless men chant, artisans remonstrate, common people relay words, close ministers exhaust their counsel, relatives supplemented observations, blind musicians and historians taught and instructed, and the elderly revised them; only then did the king deliberate; thus affairs proceeded without error.

sentences.zh: 民之有口也，猶土之有山川也，財用於是乎出：猶其有原隰衍沃也，衣食於是乎生。

translations.text: The people having mouths is like the land having mountains and rivers, from which wealth and resources come forth; it is like having plains, lowlands, marshes, and fertile fields, from which clothing and food arise.

sentences.zh: 口之宣言也，善敗於是乎興。

translations.text: When mouths proclaim words, from this arise both good and bad.

sentences.zh: 行善而備敗，所以產財用衣食者也。

translations.text: To practice good and prepare against failure is how wealth, resources, clothing, and food are produced.

sentences.zh: 夫民慮之於心而宣之於口，成而行之。

translations.text: The people consider in their hearts and proclaim with their mouths, then accomplish and act upon it.

sentences.zh: 若壅其口，其與能幾何？」

translations.text: If you block their mouths, how long can it last?"

sentences.zh: 王不聽。

translations.text: The king did not listen.

sentences.zh: 於是國莫敢出言，三年，乃相與畔，襲厲王。

translations.text: Thereupon no one in the state dared speak out; after three years, they revolted together and attacked King Li.

sentences.zh: 厲王出奔於彘。

translations.text: King Li fled to Zhi.

The king acted with cruel tyranny and extravagant arrogance, and the people of the state slandered the king. The Duke of Shao remonstrated, saying: "The people cannot bear these orders."  The king became angry, obtained a shaman from Wei, and had him spy on those who slandered; if they reported, he would kill them. Slander decreased, but the feudal lords did not come to court. In the thirty-fourth year, the king became even stricter; the people of the state dared not speak and communicated on the roads only with their eyes. King Li was pleased and told the Duke of Shao: "I can stop slander now; they dare not speak."  The Duke of Shao said: "This is blocking them. Blocking the mouths of the people is worse than blocking water. When water is dammed up and bursts through, it will surely harm many people; the people are also like this. Therefore those who manage water open channels to guide it, and those who govern people allow them to speak freely. Therefore when the Son of Heaven attended to government, he had dukes and ministers down to ranked officials present poems, blind musicians present songs, scribes present writings, preceptors offer admonitions, blind men recite, sightless men chant, artisans remonstrate, common people relay words, close ministers exhaust their counsel, relatives supplemented observations, blind musicians and historians taught and instructed, and the elderly revised them; only then did the king deliberate; thus affairs proceeded without error. The people having mouths is like the land having mountains and rivers, from which wealth and resources come forth; it is like having plains, lowlands, marshes, and fertile fields, from which clothing and food arise. When mouths proclaim words, from this arise both good and bad. To practice good and prepare against failure is how wealth, resources, clothing, and food are produced. The people consider in their hearts and proclaim with their mouths, then accomplish and act upon it. If you block their mouths, how long can it last?"  The king did not listen. Thereupon no one in the state dared speak out; after three years, they revolted together and attacked King Li. King Li fled to Zhi.

sentences.zh: 厲王太子靜匿召公之家，國人聞之，乃圍之。

translations.text: Crown Prince Jing of King Li hid in the Duke of Shao's house; when the people of the state heard of this, they surrounded it.

sentences.zh: 召公曰：「昔吾驟諫王，王不從，以及此難也。

translations.text: The Duke of Shao said: "In the past I repeatedly remonstrated with the king; the king did not listen, and it has come to this calamity.

sentences.zh: 今殺王太子，王其以我為讎而懟怒乎？

translations.text: Now if they kill the crown prince, will the king consider me his enemy and hate me with anger?

sentences.zh: 夫事君者，險而不讎懟，怨而不怒，況事王乎！」

translations.text: One who serves a lord, though in peril, does not become an enemy and resentful, though wronged, does not become angry; how much more so when serving the king!"

sentences.zh: 乃以其子代王太子，太子竟得脫。

translations.text: So he substituted his own son for the crown prince, and the crown prince managed to escape.

Crown Prince Jing of King Li hid in the Duke of Shao's house; when the people of the state heard of this, they surrounded it. The Duke of Shao said: "In the past I repeatedly remonstrated with the king; the king did not listen, and it has come to this calamity. Now if they kill the crown prince, will the king consider me his enemy and hate me with anger? One who serves a lord, though in peril, does not become an enemy and resentful, though wronged, does not become angry; how much more so when serving the king!"  So he substituted his own son for the crown prince, and the crown prince managed to escape.

sentences.zh: 召公、周公二相行政，號曰「共和」。

translations.text: The two prime ministers, the Duke of Shao and the Duke of Zhou, governed together; it was called the "Gonghe Regency."

sentences.zh: 共和十四年，厲王死于彘。

translations.text: In the fourteenth year of the Gonghe Regency, King Li died at Zhi.

sentences.zh: 太子靜長於召公家，二相乃共立之為王，是為宣王。

translations.text: Crown Prince Jing grew up in the Duke of Shao's household; the two prime ministers then jointly installed him as king; this was King Xuan.

sentences.zh: 宣王即位，二相輔之，修政，法文、武、成、康之遺風，諸侯復宗周。

translations.text: When King Xuan ascended the throne, the two prime ministers assisted him, reformed the government, modeled on the legacies of Kings Wen, Wu, Cheng, and Kang, and the feudal lords again honored Zhou.

sentences.zh: 十二年，魯武公來朝。

translations.text: In the twelfth year, Duke Wu of Lu came to court.

The two prime ministers, the Duke of Shao and the Duke of Zhou, governed together; it was called the "Gonghe Regency." In the fourteenth year of the Gonghe Regency, King Li died at Zhi. Crown Prince Jing grew up in the Duke of Shao's household; the two prime ministers then jointly installed him as king; this was King Xuan. When King Xuan ascended the throne, the two prime ministers assisted him, reformed the government, modeled on the legacies of Kings Wen, Wu, Cheng, and Kang, and the feudal lords again honored Zhou. In the twelfth year, Duke Wu of Lu came to court.

sentences.zh: 宣王不修籍於千畝，虢文公諫曰不可，王弗聽。

translations.text: King Xuan did not perform the plowing ritual at Qianmu; Guo Wengong remonstrated saying it was not acceptable, but the king did not listen.

sentences.zh: 三十九年，戰于千畝，王師敗績于姜氏之戎。

translations.text: In the thirty-ninth year, they fought at Qianmu; the royal army was defeated by the Rong of the Jiang clan.

King Xuan did not perform the plowing ritual at Qianmu; Guo Wengong remonstrated saying it was not acceptable, but the king did not listen. In the thirty-ninth year, they fought at Qianmu; the royal army was defeated by the Rong of the Jiang clan.

sentences.zh: 宣王既亡南國之師，乃料民於太原。

translations.text: After King Xuan lost the army of the southern states, he conducted a census of the people at Taiyuan.

sentences.zh: 仲山甫諫曰：「民不可料也。」

translations.text: Zhong Shanfu remonstrated, saying: "The people cannot be counted."

sentences.zh: 宣王不聽，卒料民。

translations.text: King Xuan did not listen and in the end conducted the census.

After King Xuan lost the army of the southern states, he conducted a census of the people at Taiyuan. Zhong Shanfu remonstrated, saying: "The people cannot be counted."  King Xuan did not listen and in the end conducted the census.

sentences.zh: 四十六年，宣王崩，子幽王宮湦立。

translations.text: In the forty-sixth year, King Xuan died; his son King You Gongnie succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 幽王二年，西周三川皆震。

translations.text: In the second year of King You, the three rivers of Western Zhou all experienced earthquakes.

sentences.zh: 伯陽甫曰：「周將亡矣。

translations.text: Boyang Fu said: "Zhou will perish.

sentences.zh: 夫天地之氣，不失其序；

translations.text: The qi of Heaven and Earth do not lose their proper order;

sentences.zh: 若過其序，民亂之也。

translations.text: if they exceed their order, it is because the people have thrown them into disorder.

sentences.zh: 陽伏而不能出，陰迫而不能蒸，於是有地震。

translations.text: When yang is suppressed and cannot emerge, and yin presses down and cannot rise, then there are earthquakes.

sentences.zh: 今三川實震，是陽失其所而填陰也。

translations.text: Now the three rivers have truly experienced earthquakes; this means yang has lost its position and is overwhelmed by yin.

sentences.zh: 陽失而在陰，原必塞；

translations.text: When yang is lost and buried in yin, springs will surely be blocked;

sentences.zh: 原塞，國必亡。

translations.text: when springs are blocked, the state will surely perish.

sentences.zh: 夫水土演而民用也。

translations.text: Water and soil flowing freely is what the people depend on.

sentences.zh: 土無所演，民乏財用，不亡何待！

translations.text: When the soil has no flow, the people will lack wealth and resources; if not perishing, what are we waiting for!

sentences.zh: 昔伊、洛竭而夏亡，河竭而商亡。

translations.text: In the past, the Yi and Luo dried up and Xia perished, the Yellow River dried up and Shang perished.

sentences.zh: 今周德若二代之季矣，其川原又塞，塞必竭。

translations.text: Now Zhou's virtue is like that of the last years of those two dynasties; its rivers and springs are moreover blocked, and being blocked they will surely dry up.

sentences.zh: 夫國必依山川，山崩川竭，亡國之徵也。

translations.text: A state must depend on mountains and rivers; when mountains collapse and rivers dry up, these are signs of a perishing state.

sentences.zh: 川竭必山崩。

translations.text: When rivers dry up, mountains will surely collapse.

sentences.zh: 若國亡不過十年，數之紀也。

translations.text: If the state perishes, it will be no more than ten years, which is one cycle of numbers.

sentences.zh: 天之所棄，不過其紀。」

translations.text: What Heaven abandons does not exceed its cycle."

sentences.zh: 是歲也，三川竭，岐山崩。

translations.text: In that year, the three rivers dried up and Mount Qi collapsed.

In the forty-sixth year, King Xuan died; his son King You Gongnie succeeded him. In the second year of King You, the three rivers of Western Zhou all experienced earthquakes. Boyang Fu said: "Zhou will perish. The qi of Heaven and Earth do not lose their proper order; if they exceed their order, it is because the people have thrown them into disorder. When yang is suppressed and cannot emerge, and yin presses down and cannot rise, then there are earthquakes. Now the three rivers have truly experienced earthquakes; this means yang has lost its position and is overwhelmed by yin. When yang is lost and buried in yin, springs will surely be blocked; when springs are blocked, the state will surely perish. Water and soil flowing freely is what the people depend on. When the soil has no flow, the people will lack wealth and resources; if not perishing, what are we waiting for! In the past, the Yi and Luo dried up and Xia perished, the Yellow River dried up and Shang perished. Now Zhou's virtue is like that of the last years of those two dynasties; its rivers and springs are moreover blocked, and being blocked they will surely dry up. A state must depend on mountains and rivers; when mountains collapse and rivers dry up, these are signs of a perishing state. When rivers dry up, mountains will surely collapse. If the state perishes, it will be no more than ten years, which is one cycle of numbers. What Heaven abandons does not exceed its cycle."  In that year, the three rivers dried up and Mount Qi collapsed.

sentences.zh: 三年，幽王嬖愛褒姒。

translations.text: In the third year, King You doted on and loved Bao Si.

sentences.zh: 褒姒生子伯服，幽王欲廢太子。

translations.text: Bao Si gave birth to a son, Bofu, and King You wanted to depose the crown prince.

sentences.zh: 太子母申侯女，而為后。

translations.text: The crown prince's mother was a daughter of the Marquis of Shen and had become queen.

sentences.zh: 後幽王得褒姒，愛之，欲廢申后，并去太子宜臼，以褒姒為后，以伯服為太子。

translations.text: Later when King You obtained Bao Si, he loved her and wanted to depose Queen Shen, also removing Crown Prince Yijiu, making Bao Si the queen and Bofu the crown prince.

sentences.zh: 周太史伯陽讀史記曰：「周亡矣。」

translations.text: The Grand Historian of Zhou, Boyang, read the historical records and said: "Zhou will perish."

sentences.zh: 昔自夏后氏之衰也，有二神龍止於夏帝庭而言曰：「余，褒之二君。」

translations.text: Long ago when the Xia declined, two divine dragons appeared in the court of the Xia emperor and said: 'We are the two lords of Bao.'

sentences.zh: 夏帝卜殺之與去之與止之，莫吉。

translations.text: The Xia emperor divined whether to kill them, drive them away, or keep them; none was auspicious.

sentences.zh: 卜請其漦而藏之，乃吉。

translations.text: He divined about requesting their saliva and storing it; this was auspicious.

sentences.zh: 於是布幣而策告之，龍亡而漦在，櫝而去之。

translations.text: Thereupon he presented ritual gifts and made an announcement with divination tablets; the dragons disappeared but the saliva remained, and he put it in a box and stored it away.

sentences.zh: 夏亡，傳此器殷。

translations.text: When Xia perished, this vessel was transmitted to Yin.

sentences.zh: 殷亡，又傳此器周。

translations.text: When Yin perished, this vessel was again transmitted to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 比三代，莫敢發之，至厲王之末，發而觀之。

translations.text: Throughout all three dynasties, none dared to open it; until the end of King Li's reign, when it was opened and examined.

sentences.zh: 漦流于庭，不可除。

translations.text: The saliva flowed in the courtyard and could not be removed.

sentences.zh: 厲王使婦人裸而譟之。

translations.text: King Li had women strip naked and shout at it.

sentences.zh: 漦化為玄黿，以入王後宮。

translations.text: The saliva transformed into a black turtle and entered the king's rear palace.

sentences.zh: 後宮之童妾既齔而遭之，既笄而孕，無夫而生子，懼而棄之。

translations.text: A young maid in the rear palace encountered it when she had lost her baby teeth, became pregnant when she came of age, and gave birth to a child without a husband; frightened, she abandoned it.

sentences.zh: 宣王之時童女謠曰：「厭弧箕服，實亡周國。」

translations.text: In King Xuan's time, young girls sang a ditty: 'A bow of wild mulberry and quiver of wicker will truly destroy the Zhou state.'

sentences.zh: 於是宣王聞之，有夫婦賣是器者，宣王使執而戮之。

translations.text: When King Xuan heard this, there was a couple selling such implements, and King Xuan had them arrested and executed.

sentences.zh: 逃於道，而見鄉者後宮童妾所棄妖子出於路者，聞其夜啼，哀而收之，夫婦遂亡，奔於褒。

translations.text: They fled on the road and saw the ominous child that had been abandoned by the rear palace maid lying on the road; hearing her cry at night, they pitied her and took her in, and the couple then escaped and fled to Bao.

sentences.zh: 褒人有罪，請入童妾所棄女子者於王以贖罪。

translations.text: The people of Bao committed a crime and requested to present the girl abandoned by the maid to the king to redeem their crime.

sentences.zh: 棄女子出於褒，是為褒姒。

translations.text: The abandoned girl came from Bao; this was Bao Si.

sentences.zh: 當幽王三年，王之後宮見而愛之，生子伯服，竟廢申后及太子，以褒姒為后，伯服為太子。

translations.text: In King You's third year, when the king's rear palace saw her, he loved her; she gave birth to a son Bofu, and he finally deposed Queen Shen and the crown prince, making Bao Si the queen and Bofu the crown prince.

sentences.zh: 太史伯陽曰：「禍成矣，無可奈何！」

translations.text: Grand Historian Boyang said: "The disaster is complete; there is nothing that can be done!"

In the third year, King You doted on and loved Bao Si. Bao Si gave birth to a son, Bofu, and King You wanted to depose the crown prince. The crown prince's mother was a daughter of the Marquis of Shen and had become queen. Later when King You obtained Bao Si, he loved her and wanted to depose Queen Shen, also removing Crown Prince Yijiu, making Bao Si the queen and Bofu the crown prince. The Grand Historian of Zhou, Boyang, read the historical records and said: "Zhou will perish."  Long ago when the Xia declined, two divine dragons appeared in the court of the Xia emperor and said: 'We are the two lords of Bao.'  The Xia emperor divined whether to kill them, drive them away, or keep them; none was auspicious. He divined about requesting their saliva and storing it; this was auspicious. Thereupon he presented ritual gifts and made an announcement with divination tablets; the dragons disappeared but the saliva remained, and he put it in a box and stored it away. When Xia perished, this vessel was transmitted to Yin. When Yin perished, this vessel was again transmitted to Zhou. Throughout all three dynasties, none dared to open it; until the end of King Li's reign, when it was opened and examined. The saliva flowed in the courtyard and could not be removed. King Li had women strip naked and shout at it. The saliva transformed into a black turtle and entered the king's rear palace. A young maid in the rear palace encountered it when she had lost her baby teeth, became pregnant when she came of age, and gave birth to a child without a husband; frightened, she abandoned it. In King Xuan's time, young girls sang a ditty: 'A bow of wild mulberry and quiver of wicker will truly destroy the Zhou state.'  When King Xuan heard this, there was a couple selling such implements, and King Xuan had them arrested and executed. They fled on the road and saw the ominous child that had been abandoned by the rear palace maid lying on the road; hearing her cry at night, they pitied her and took her in, and the couple then escaped and fled to Bao. The people of Bao committed a crime and requested to present the girl abandoned by the maid to the king to redeem their crime. The abandoned girl came from Bao; this was Bao Si. In King You's third year, when the king's rear palace saw her, he loved her; she gave birth to a son Bofu, and he finally deposed Queen Shen and the crown prince, making Bao Si the queen and Bofu the crown prince. Grand Historian Boyang said: "The disaster is complete; there is nothing that can be done!"

sentences.zh: 褒姒不好笑，幽王欲其笑萬方，故不笑。

translations.text: Bao Si did not like to smile; King You tried by every means to make her smile, but still she would not smile.

sentences.zh: 幽王為烽燧大鼓，有寇至則舉烽火。

translations.text: King You set up beacon fires and great drums; when invaders came, the beacon fires would be lit.

sentences.zh: 諸侯悉至，至而無寇，褒姒乃大笑。

translations.text: All the feudal lords arrived, but when they arrived there were no invaders, and Bao Si then laughed heartily.

sentences.zh: 幽王說之，為數舉烽火。

translations.text: King You was pleased by this and repeatedly lit the beacon fires.

sentences.zh: 其後不信，諸侯益亦不至。

translations.text: Afterward they lost trust, and the feudal lords increasingly did not come.

Bao Si did not like to smile; King You tried by every means to make her smile, but still she would not smile. King You set up beacon fires and great drums; when invaders came, the beacon fires would be lit. All the feudal lords arrived, but when they arrived there were no invaders, and Bao Si then laughed heartily. King You was pleased by this and repeatedly lit the beacon fires. Afterward they lost trust, and the feudal lords increasingly did not come.

sentences.zh: 幽王以虢石父為卿，用事，國人皆怨。

translations.text: King You made Guo Shifu a minister and put him in charge of affairs; all the people of the state resented this.

sentences.zh: 石父為人佞巧善諛好利，王用之。

translations.text: Shifu was a person who was cunning, artful, good at flattery, and fond of profit, yet the king employed him.

sentences.zh: 又廢申后，去太子也。

translations.text: Moreover he deposed Queen Shen and removed the crown prince.

sentences.zh: 申侯怒，與繒、西夷犬戎攻幽王。

translations.text: The Marquis of Shen became angry and together with Zeng and the Western Yi Quanrong attacked King You.

sentences.zh: 幽王舉烽火徵兵，兵莫至。

translations.text: King You lit the beacon fires to summon troops, but no troops came.

sentences.zh: 遂殺幽王驪山下，虜褒姒，盡取周賂而去。

translations.text: They then killed King You at the foot of Mount Li, captured Bao Si, took all of Zhou's treasures, and departed.

sentences.zh: 於是諸侯乃即申侯而共立故幽王太子宜臼，是為平王，以奉周祀。

translations.text: Thereupon the feudal lords went to the Marquis of Shen and jointly installed the former crown prince of King You, Yijiu; this was King Ping, to continue Zhou's sacrifices.

King You made Guo Shifu a minister and put him in charge of affairs; all the people of the state resented this. Shifu was a person who was cunning, artful, good at flattery, and fond of profit, yet the king employed him. Moreover he deposed Queen Shen and removed the crown prince. The Marquis of Shen became angry and together with Zeng and the Western Yi Quanrong attacked King You. King You lit the beacon fires to summon troops, but no troops came. They then killed King You at the foot of Mount Li, captured Bao Si, took all of Zhou's treasures, and departed. Thereupon the feudal lords went to the Marquis of Shen and jointly installed the former crown prince of King You, Yijiu; this was King Ping, to continue Zhou's sacrifices.

sentences.zh: 平王立，東遷于雒邑，辟戎寇。

translations.text: When King Ping was installed, he moved east to Luoyi to avoid the Rong invaders.

sentences.zh: 平王之時，周室衰微，諸侯彊并弱，齊、楚、秦、晉始大，政由方伯。

translations.text: In King Ping's time, the Zhou royal house was weak and declining; the strong feudal lords annexed the weak, Qi, Chu, Qin, and Jin began to grow powerful, and government came from the regional lords.

When King Ping was installed, he moved east to Luoyi to avoid the Rong invaders. In King Ping's time, the Zhou royal house was weak and declining; the strong feudal lords annexed the weak, Qi, Chu, Qin, and Jin began to grow powerful, and government came from the regional lords.

sentences.zh: 四十九年，魯隱公即位。

translations.text: In the forty-ninth year, Duke Yin of Lu ascended the throne.
In the forty-ninth year, Duke Yin of Lu ascended the throne.

sentences.zh: 五十一年，平王崩，太子洩父蚤死，立其子林，是為桓王。

translations.text: In the fifty-first year, King Ping died; Crown Prince Xiefu had died early, so his son Lin was installed; this was King Huan.

sentences.zh: 桓王，平王孫也。

translations.text: King Huan was King Ping's grandson.
In the fifty-first year, King Ping died; Crown Prince Xiefu had died early, so his son Lin was installed; this was King Huan. King Huan was King Ping's grandson.

sentences.zh: 桓王三年，鄭莊公朝，桓王不禮。

translations.text: In the third year of King Huan, Duke Zhuang of Zheng came to court, but King Huan did not treat him with proper courtesy.

sentences.zh: 五年，鄭怨，與魯易許田。

translations.text: In the fifth year, Zheng, bearing resentment, exchanged the Xu fields with Lu.

sentences.zh: 許田，天子之用事太山田也。

translations.text: The Xu fields were the Son of Heaven's fields for conducting affairs at Mount Tai.

sentences.zh: 八年，魯殺隱公，立桓公。

translations.text: In the eighth year, Lu killed Duke Yin and installed Duke Huan.

sentences.zh: 十三年，伐鄭，鄭射傷桓王，桓王去歸。

translations.text: In the thirteenth year, he attacked Zheng; Zheng shot and wounded King Huan, and King Huan withdrew and returned.

In the third year of King Huan, Duke Zhuang of Zheng came to court, but King Huan did not treat him with proper courtesy. In the fifth year, Zheng, bearing resentment, exchanged the Xu fields with Lu. The Xu fields were the Son of Heaven's fields for conducting affairs at Mount Tai. In the eighth year, Lu killed Duke Yin and installed Duke Huan. In the thirteenth year, he attacked Zheng; Zheng shot and wounded King Huan, and King Huan withdrew and returned.

sentences.zh: 二十三年，桓王崩，子莊王佗立。

translations.text: In the twenty-third year, King Huan died; his son King Zhuang Tuo succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 莊王四年，周公黑肩欲殺莊王而立王子克。

translations.text: In the fourth year of King Zhuang, the Duke of Zhou Heijian wanted to kill King Zhuang and install Prince Ke.

sentences.zh: 辛伯告王，王殺周公。

translations.text: Xin Bo informed the king, and the king killed the Duke of Zhou.

sentences.zh: 王子克奔燕。

translations.text: Prince Ke fled to Yan.

In the twenty-third year, King Huan died; his son King Zhuang Tuo succeeded him. In the fourth year of King Zhuang, the Duke of Zhou Heijian wanted to kill King Zhuang and install Prince Ke. Xin Bo informed the king, and the king killed the Duke of Zhou. Prince Ke fled to Yan.

sentences.zh: 十五年，莊王崩，子釐王胡齊立。

translations.text: In the fifteenth year, King Zhuang died; his son King Xi Huqi succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 釐王三年，齊桓公始霸。

translations.text: In the third year of King Xi, Duke Huan of Qi first became hegemon.
In the fifteenth year, King Zhuang died; his son King Xi Huqi succeeded him. In the third year of King Xi, Duke Huan of Qi first became hegemon.

sentences.zh: 五年，釐王崩，子惠王閬立。

translations.text: In the fifth year, King Xi died; his son King Hui Lang succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 惠王二年。

translations.text: In the second year of King Hui:

sentences.zh: 初，莊王嬖姬姚，生子穨，穨有寵。

translations.text: Initially, King Zhuang had favored Concubine Yao, who gave birth to a son Tui, and Tui was favored.

sentences.zh: 及惠王即位，奪其大臣以為囿，故大夫邊伯等五人作亂，謀召燕、衛師，伐惠王。

translations.text: When King Hui ascended the throne, he seized lands from his great ministers to make a park; therefore Grand Masters Bian Bo and four others created disorder, plotted to summon armies from Yan and Wei, and attacked King Hui.

sentences.zh: 惠王犇溫，已居鄭之櫟。

translations.text: King Hui fled to Wen and then resided at Zheng's Li.

sentences.zh: 立釐王弟穨為王。

translations.text: They installed King Xi's younger brother Tui as king.

sentences.zh: 樂及徧舞，鄭、虢君怒。

translations.text: He enjoyed music including ritual dances, and the lords of Zheng and Guo became angry.

sentences.zh: 四年，鄭與虢君伐殺王穨，復入惠王。

translations.text: In the fourth year, Zheng and the lord of Guo attacked and killed King Tui, and restored King Hui.

sentences.zh: 惠王十年，賜齊桓公為伯。

translations.text: In the tenth year of King Hui, he bestowed upon Duke Huan of Qi the title of hegemon.

In the fifth year, King Xi died; his son King Hui Lang succeeded him. In the second year of King Hui: Initially, King Zhuang had favored Concubine Yao, who gave birth to a son Tui, and Tui was favored. When King Hui ascended the throne, he seized lands from his great ministers to make a park; therefore Grand Masters Bian Bo and four others created disorder, plotted to summon armies from Yan and Wei, and attacked King Hui. King Hui fled to Wen and then resided at Zheng's Li. They installed King Xi's younger brother Tui as king. He enjoyed music including ritual dances, and the lords of Zheng and Guo became angry. In the fourth year, Zheng and the lord of Guo attacked and killed King Tui, and restored King Hui. In the tenth year of King Hui, he bestowed upon Duke Huan of Qi the title of hegemon.

sentences.zh: 二十五年，惠王崩，子襄王鄭立。

translations.text: In the twenty-fifth year, King Hui died; his son King Xiang Zheng succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 襄王母蚤死，後母曰惠后。

translations.text: King Xiang's mother had died early; his stepmother was called Queen Hui.

sentences.zh: 惠后生叔帶，有寵於惠王，襄王畏之。

translations.text: Queen Hui gave birth to Shu Dai, who was favored by King Hui, and King Xiang feared him.

sentences.zh: 三年，叔帶與戎、翟謀伐襄王，襄王欲誅叔帶，叔帶奔齊。

translations.text: In the third year, Shu Dai plotted with the Rong and Di to attack King Xiang; King Xiang wanted to execute Shu Dai, so Shu Dai fled to Qi.

sentences.zh: 齊桓公使管仲平戎于周，使隰朋平戎于晉。

translations.text: Duke Huan of Qi sent Guan Zhong to make peace with the Rong at Zhou and sent Xi Peng to make peace with the Rong at Jin.

sentences.zh: 王以上卿禮管仲。

translations.text: The king treated Guan Zhong with the courtesy due to an upper minister.

sentences.zh: 管仲辭曰：「臣賤有司也，有天子之二守國、高在。

translations.text: Guan Zhong declined, saying: "I am a lowly official; the Son of Heaven has two guardians of the state, Guo and Gao.

sentences.zh: 若節春秋來承王命，何以禮焉。

translations.text: If our lord comes in spring and autumn to receive the king's commands, how should I be treated with such courtesy?

sentences.zh: 陪臣敢辭。」

translations.text: This subordinate minister dares to decline."

sentences.zh: 王曰：「舅氏，余嘉乃勳，毋逆朕命。」

translations.text: The king said: "Uncle, I appreciate your meritorious service; do not oppose my command."

sentences.zh: 管仲卒受下卿之禮而還。

translations.text: Guan Zhong in the end accepted the courtesy due to a lower minister and returned.

sentences.zh: 九年，齊桓公卒。

translations.text: In the ninth year, Duke Huan of Qi died.

sentences.zh: 十二年，叔帶復歸于周。

translations.text: In the twelfth year, Shu Dai returned to Zhou.

In the twenty-fifth year, King Hui died; his son King Xiang Zheng succeeded him. King Xiang's mother had died early; his stepmother was called Queen Hui. Queen Hui gave birth to Shu Dai, who was favored by King Hui, and King Xiang feared him. In the third year, Shu Dai plotted with the Rong and Di to attack King Xiang; King Xiang wanted to execute Shu Dai, so Shu Dai fled to Qi. Duke Huan of Qi sent Guan Zhong to make peace with the Rong at Zhou and sent Xi Peng to make peace with the Rong at Jin. The king treated Guan Zhong with the courtesy due to an upper minister. Guan Zhong declined, saying: "I am a lowly official; the Son of Heaven has two guardians of the state, Guo and Gao. If our lord comes in spring and autumn to receive the king's commands, how should I be treated with such courtesy? This subordinate minister dares to decline."  The king said: "Uncle, I appreciate your meritorious service; do not oppose my command."  Guan Zhong in the end accepted the courtesy due to a lower minister and returned. In the ninth year, Duke Huan of Qi died. In the twelfth year, Shu Dai returned to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 十三年，鄭伐滑，王使游孫、伯服請滑，鄭人囚之。

translations.text: In the thirteenth year, Zheng attacked Hua; the king sent You Sun and Bo Fu to plead for Hua, but the Zheng people imprisoned them.

sentences.zh: 鄭文公怨惠王之入不與厲公爵，又怨襄王之與衛滑，故囚伯服。

translations.text: Duke Wen of Zheng resented that when King Hui was restored he did not give Duke Li his noble title, and also resented that King Xiang gave Hua to Wei, therefore he imprisoned Bo Fu.

sentences.zh: 王怒，將以翟伐鄭。

translations.text: The king was angry and intended to use the Di to attack Zheng.

sentences.zh: 富辰諫曰：「凡我周之東徙，晉、鄭焉依。

translations.text: Fu Chen remonstrated, saying: "When our Zhou moved east, we relied on Jin and Zheng.

sentences.zh: 子穨之亂，又鄭之由定，今以小怨棄之！」

translations.text: During Prince Tui's rebellion, it was also through Zheng that it was settled; now to abandon them for a small grievance!"

sentences.zh: 王不聽。

translations.text: The king did not listen.

sentences.zh: 十五年，王降翟師以伐鄭。

translations.text: In the fifteenth year, the king brought down a Di army to attack Zheng.

sentences.zh: 王德翟人，將以其女為后。

translations.text: The king was grateful to the Di people and intended to make their daughter queen.

sentences.zh: 富辰諫曰：「平、桓、莊、惠皆受鄭勞，王棄親親翟，不可從。」

translations.text: Fu Chen remonstrated, saying: "Kings Ping, Huan, Zhuang, and Hui all received service from Zheng; for the king to abandon kinsmen and draw close to the Di is unacceptable."

sentences.zh: 王不聽。

translations.text: The king did not listen.

sentences.zh: 十六年，王絀翟后，翟人來誅，殺譚伯。

translations.text: In the sixteenth year, the king deposed the Di queen; the Di people came to punish him and killed Tan Bo.

sentences.zh: 富辰曰：「吾數諫不從。

translations.text: Fu Chen said: "I repeatedly remonstrated but was not heeded.

sentences.zh: 如是不出，王以我為懟乎？」

translations.text: If I do not go out under these circumstances, will the king consider me resentful?"

sentences.zh: 乃以其屬死之。

translations.text: So he and his followers died in battle.

In the thirteenth year, Zheng attacked Hua; the king sent You Sun and Bo Fu to plead for Hua, but the Zheng people imprisoned them. Duke Wen of Zheng resented that when King Hui was restored he did not give Duke Li his noble title, and also resented that King Xiang gave Hua to Wei, therefore he imprisoned Bo Fu. The king was angry and intended to use the Di to attack Zheng. Fu Chen remonstrated, saying: "When our Zhou moved east, we relied on Jin and Zheng. During Prince Tui's rebellion, it was also through Zheng that it was settled; now to abandon them for a small grievance!"  The king did not listen. In the fifteenth year, the king brought down a Di army to attack Zheng. The king was grateful to the Di people and intended to make their daughter queen. sentences.zh: 子帶立為王，取襄王所絀翟后與居溫。

sentences.zh: 十七年，襄王告急于晉，晉文公納王而誅叔帶。

translations.text: In the seventeenth year, King Xiang appealed for help to Jin; Duke Wen of Jin restored the king and executed Shu Dai.

sentences.zh: 襄王乃賜晉文公珪鬯弓矢，為伯，以河內地與晉。

translations.text: King Xiang thereupon bestowed upon Duke Wen of Jin jade tablets, aromatic wine, bows and arrows, made him hegemon, and gave the lands within the Yellow River to Jin.

translations.text: In the first year of King Ding, King Zhuang of Chu attacked the Rong of Luhun, camped at Luo, and sent someone to inquire about the Nine Tripods.

sentences.zh: 簡王十三年，晉殺其君厲公，迎子周於周，立為悼公。

translations.text: In the fourteenth year, King Jian died; his son King Ling Xiexin succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 靈王二十四年，齊崔杼弒其君莊公。

translations.text: In the twenty-seventh year, King Ling died; his son King Jing Gui succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 景王十八年，后太子聖而蚤卒。

translations.text: In the eighteenth year of King Jing, the later crown prince Sheng died early.

sentences.zh: 二十年，景王愛子朝，欲立之，會崩，子丐之黨與爭立，國人立長子猛為王，子朝攻殺猛。

translations.text: In the twentieth year, King Jing loved Prince Zhao and wanted to install him, but then died; Prince Gai's faction struggled for power; the people of the state installed the eldest son Meng as king, but Prince Zhao attacked and killed Meng.

sentences.zh: 猛為悼王。

sentences.zh: 四年，晉率諸侯入敬王于周，子朝為臣，諸侯城周。

translations.text: In the fourth year, Jin led the feudal lords and installed King Jing in Zhou; Prince Zhao became a minister, and the feudal lords fortified Zhou.

sentences.zh: 十六年，子朝之徒復作亂，敬王奔于晉。

translations.text: In the sixteenth year, Prince Zhao's followers again created disorder, and King Jing fled to Jin.

sentences.zh: 十七年，晉定公遂入敬王于周。

translations.text: In the seventeenth year, Duke Ding of Jin then installed King Jing in Zhou.

translations.text: In the thirty-ninth year, Tian Chang of Qi killed his lord Duke Jian.
In the thirty-ninth year, Tian Chang of Qi killed his lord Duke Jian.

sentences.zh: 四十一年，楚滅陳。

translations.text: In the forty-first year, Chu destroyed Chen.

translations.text: Confucius died.
In the forty-first year, Chu destroyed Chen. Confucius died.

sentences.zh: 四十二年，敬王崩，子元王仁立。

translations.text: In the forty-second year, King Jing died; his son King Yuan Ren succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 元王八年，崩，子定王介立。

translations.text: In the eighth year of King Yuan, he died; his son King Ding Jie succeeded him.
In the forty-second year, King Jing died; his son King Yuan Ren succeeded him. In the eighth year of King Yuan, he died; his son King Ding Jie succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 定王十六年，三晉滅智伯，分有其地。

translations.text: In the sixteenth year of King Ding, the Three Jin destroyed Zhi Bo and divided his territory.
In the sixteenth year of King Ding, the Three Jin destroyed Zhi Bo and divided his territory.

sentences.zh: 二十八年，定王崩，長子去疾立，是為哀王。

translations.text: In the twenty-eighth year, King Ding died; his eldest son Quji succeeded him; this was King Ai.

sentences.zh: 哀王立三月，弟叔襲殺哀王而自立，是為思王。

translations.text: King Ai reigned for three months when his brother Shu attacked and killed King Ai and installed himself; this was King Si.

sentences.zh: 思王立五月，少弟嵬攻殺思王而自立，是為考王。

translations.text: King Si reigned for five months when his younger brother Wei attacked and killed King Si and installed himself; this was King Kao.

sentences.zh: 此三王皆定王之子。

translations.text: These three kings were all sons of King Ding.

King Si reigned for five months when his younger brother Wei attacked and killed King Si and installed himself; this was King Kao. These three kings were all sons of King Ding.

sentences.zh: 考王十五年，崩，子威烈王午立。

translations.text: In the fifteenth year of King Kao, he died; his son King Weilie Wu succeeded him.
In the fifteenth year of King Kao, he died; his son King Weilie Wu succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 考王封其弟于河南，是為桓公，以續周公之官職。

translations.text: King Kao enfeoffed his brother at Henan; this was Duke Huan, to continue the Duke of Zhou's official position.

sentences.zh: 桓公卒，子威公代立。

translations.text: When Duke Huan died, his son Duke Wei succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 威公卒，子惠公代立，乃封其少子於鞏以奉王，號東周惠公。

translations.text: When Duke Wei died, his son Duke Hui succeeded him; he then enfeoffed his youngest son at Gong to serve the king, titled the Duke Hui of Eastern Zhou.

sentences.zh: 威烈王二十三年，九鼎震。

translations.text: In the twenty-third year of King Weilie, the Nine Tripods shook.

sentences.zh: 命韓、魏、趙為諸侯。

translations.text: He commanded that Han, Wei, and Zhao be made feudal lords.
In the twenty-third year of King Weilie, the Nine Tripods shook. He commanded that Han, Wei, and Zhao be made feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 二十四年，崩，子安王驕立。

translations.text: In the twenty-fourth year, he died; his son King An Jiao succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 是歲盜殺楚聲王。

translations.text: In that year, bandits killed King Sheng of Chu.
In the twenty-fourth year, he died; his son King An Jiao succeeded him. In that year, bandits killed King Sheng of Chu.

sentences.zh: 安王立二十六年，崩，子烈王喜立。

translations.text: King An reigned for twenty-six years and died; his son King Lie Xi succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 烈王二年，周太史儋見秦獻公曰：「始周與秦國合而別，別五百載復合，合十七歲而霸王者出焉。」

translations.text: In the second year of King Lie, the Grand Historian of Zhou Dan met Duke Xian of Qin and said: "At the beginning Zhou and the state of Qin joined and then separated; after five hundred years of separation they will reunite, and seventeen years after reuniting a hegemon-king will emerge."

sentences.zh: 十年，烈王崩，弟扁立，是為顯王。

translations.text: In the tenth year, King Lie died; his younger brother Bian succeeded him; this was King Xian.

sentences.zh: 顯王五年，賀秦獻公，獻公稱伯。

translations.text: In the fifth year of King Xian, he congratulated Duke Xian of Qin, and Duke Xian claimed the title of hegemon.

sentences.zh: 九年，致文武胙於秦孝公。

translations.text: In the ninth year, he sent sacrificial meat from King Wen and King Wu to Duke Xiao of Qin.

sentences.zh: 二十五年，秦會諸侯於周。

translations.text: In the twenty-fifth year, Qin convened the feudal lords at Zhou.

sentences.zh: 二十六年，周致伯於秦孝公。

translations.text: In the twenty-sixth year, Zhou bestowed the title of hegemon upon Duke Xiao of Qin.

sentences.zh: 三十三年，賀秦惠王。

translations.text: In the thirty-third year, he congratulated King Hui of Qin.

sentences.zh: 三十五年，致文武胙於秦惠王。

translations.text: In the thirty-fifth year, he sent sacrificial meat from King Wen and King Wu to King Hui of Qin.

sentences.zh: 四十四年，秦惠王稱王。

translations.text: In the forty-fourth year, King Hui of Qin claimed the title of king.

sentences.zh: 其後諸侯皆為王。

translations.text: After that, all the feudal lords became kings.

sentences.zh: 四十八年，顯王崩，子慎靚王定立。

translations.text: In the forty-eighth year, King Xian died; his son King Shenjing Ding succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 慎靚王立六年，崩，子赧王延立。

translations.text: King Shenjing reigned for six years and died; his son King Nan Yan succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 王赧時東西周分治。

translations.text: In King Nan's time, Eastern and Western Zhou were separately governed.

sentences.zh: 王赧徙都西周。

translations.text: King Nan moved the capital to Western Zhou.

In the forty-eighth year, King Xian died; his son King Shenjing Ding succeeded him. King Shenjing reigned for six years and died; his son King Nan Yan succeeded him. In King Nan's time, Eastern and Western Zhou were separately governed. King Nan moved the capital to Western Zhou.

sentences.zh: 西周武公之共太子死，有五庶子，毋適立。

translations.text: When the crown prince of Duke Wu of Western Zhou died, there were five illegitimate sons, and none was designated as heir.

sentences.zh: 司馬翦謂楚王曰：「不如以地資公子咎，為請太子。」

translations.text: Sima Jian said to the King of Chu: "It would be better to provide Prince Jiu with territory and request that he be made crown prince."

sentences.zh: 左成曰：「不可。

translations.text: Zuo Cheng said: "That is not advisable.

sentences.zh: 周不聽，是公之知困而交疏於周也。

translations.text: If Zhou does not listen, it means your wisdom is hampered and your relationship with Zhou becomes distant.

sentences.zh: 不如請周君孰欲立，以微告翦，翦請令楚（賀）［資］之以地。」

translations.text: It would be better to ask the lord of Zhou whom he wishes to install, subtly inform Jian, and have Jian request that Chu provide him with territory."

sentences.zh: 果立公子咎為太子。

translations.text: Indeed, Prince Jiu was installed as crown prince.

When the crown prince of Duke Wu of Western Zhou died, there were five illegitimate sons, and none was designated as heir. Sima Jian said to the King of Chu: "It would be better to provide Prince Jiu with territory and request that he be made crown prince."  Zuo Cheng said: "That is not advisable. If Zhou does not listen, it means your wisdom is hampered and your relationship with Zhou becomes distant. It would be better to ask the lord of Zhou whom he wishes to install, subtly inform Jian, and have Jian request that Chu provide him with territory."  Indeed, Prince Jiu was installed as crown prince.

sentences.zh: 八年，秦攻宜陽，楚救之。

translations.text: In the eighth year, Qin attacked Yiyang, and Chu rescued it.

sentences.zh: 而楚以周為秦故，將伐之。

translations.text: But Chu considered Zhou to be in league with Qin and intended to attack it.

sentences.zh: 蘇代為周說楚王曰：「何以周為秦之禍也？

translations.text: Su Dai persuaded the King of Chu on Zhou's behalf, saying: "Why do you consider Zhou to be Qin's disaster?

sentences.zh: 言周之為秦甚於楚者，欲令周入秦也，故謂『周秦』也。

translations.text: Those who say Zhou serves Qin more than Chu want to make Zhou submit to Qin; therefore they call it 'Zhou-Qin.'

sentences.zh: 周知其不可解，必入於秦，此為秦取周之精者也。

translations.text: If Zhou knows it cannot be resolved, it will surely submit to Qin; this is how Qin acquires the essence of Zhou.

sentences.zh: 為王計者，周於秦因善之，不於秦亦言善之，以疏之於秦。

translations.text: In planning for the king: if Zhou leans toward Qin, then speak well of it; if it does not lean toward Qin, also speak well of it, to distance it from Qin.

sentences.zh: 周絕於秦，必入於郢矣。」

translations.text: If Zhou is severed from Qin, it will surely come to Ying."

In the eighth year, Qin attacked Yiyang, and Chu rescued it. But Chu considered Zhou to be in league with Qin and intended to attack it. Su Dai persuaded the King of Chu on Zhou's behalf, saying: "Why do you consider Zhou to be Qin's disaster? Those who say Zhou serves Qin more than Chu want to make Zhou submit to Qin; therefore they call it 'Zhou-Qin.' If Zhou knows it cannot be resolved, it will surely submit to Qin; this is how Qin acquires the essence of Zhou. In planning for the king: if Zhou leans toward Qin, then speak well of it; if it does not lean toward Qin, also speak well of it, to distance it from Qin. If Zhou is severed from Qin, it will surely come to Ying."

sentences.zh: 秦借道兩周之閒，將以伐韓，周恐借之畏於韓，不借畏於秦。

translations.text: Qin requested passage between the Two Zhous in order to attack Han; Zhou feared that if they granted passage Han would be afraid of them, and if they did not grant it Qin would be afraid of them.

sentences.zh: 史厭謂周君曰：「何不令人謂韓公叔曰『秦之敢絕周而伐韓者，信東周也。

translations.text: Shi Yan said to the lord of Zhou: "Why not have someone say to Gongshu of Han: 'The reason Qin dares to cut off Zhou and attack Han is because they trust Eastern Zhou.

sentences.zh: 公何不與周地，發質使之楚』？

translations.text: Why don't you give territory to Zhou, send a hostage, and dispatch them to Chu'?

sentences.zh: 秦必疑楚不信周，是韓不伐也。

translations.text: Qin will surely suspect that Chu does not trust Zhou, and thus Han will not be attacked.

sentences.zh: 又謂秦曰『韓彊與周地，將以疑周於秦也，周不敢不受』。

translations.text: Also say to Qin: 'Han is forcing territory upon Zhou in order to make Qin suspicious of Zhou; Zhou dares not refuse.'

sentences.zh: 秦必無辭而令周不受，是受地於韓而聽於秦。」

translations.text: Qin will surely have no pretext and tell Zhou not to accept; this way you receive territory from Han while obeying Qin."

Qin requested passage between the Two Zhous in order to attack Han; Zhou feared that if they granted passage Han would be afraid of them, and if they did not grant it Qin would be afraid of them. Shi Yan said to the lord of Zhou: "Why not have someone say to Gongshu of Han: 'The reason Qin dares to cut off Zhou and attack Han is because they trust Eastern Zhou. Why don't you give territory to Zhou, send a hostage, and dispatch them to Chu'? Qin will surely suspect that Chu does not trust Zhou, and thus Han will not be attacked. Also say to Qin: 'Han is forcing territory upon Zhou in order to make Qin suspicious of Zhou; Zhou dares not refuse.' Qin will surely have no pretext and tell Zhou not to accept; this way you receive territory from Han while obeying Qin."

sentences.zh: 秦召西周君，西周君惡往，故令人謂韓王曰：「秦召西周君，將以使攻王之南陽也，王何不出兵於南陽？

translations.text: Qin summoned the lord of Western Zhou, but the lord of Western Zhou did not want to go, so he had someone say to the King of Han: "Qin has summoned the lord of Western Zhou in order to have him attack your Nanyang; why don't you deploy troops at Nanyang?

sentences.zh: 周君將以為辭於秦。

translations.text: The lord of Zhou will use this as an excuse to Qin.

sentences.zh: 周君不入秦，秦必不敢踰河而攻南陽矣。」

translations.text: If the lord of Zhou does not go to Qin, Qin will surely not dare cross the river and attack Nanyang."

Qin summoned the lord of Western Zhou, but the lord of Western Zhou did not want to go, so he had someone say to the King of Han: "Qin has summoned the lord of Western Zhou in order to have him attack your Nanyang; why don't you deploy troops at Nanyang? The lord of Zhou will use this as an excuse to Qin. If the lord of Zhou does not go to Qin, Qin will surely not dare cross the river and attack Nanyang."

sentences.zh: 東周與西周戰，韓救西周。

translations.text: Eastern Zhou and Western Zhou fought, and Han rescued Western Zhou.

sentences.zh: 或為東周說韓王曰：「西周故天子之國，多名器重寶。

translations.text: Someone persuaded the King of Han on behalf of Eastern Zhou, saying: "Western Zhou was formerly the Son of Heaven's state and has many famous vessels and precious treasures.

sentences.zh: 王案兵毋出，可以德東周，而西周之寶必可以盡矣。」

translations.text: If you hold your troops and do not deploy them, you can win Eastern Zhou's gratitude, and Western Zhou's treasures can surely all be obtained."

Eastern Zhou and Western Zhou fought, and Han rescued Western Zhou. Someone persuaded the King of Han on behalf of Eastern Zhou, saying: "Western Zhou was formerly the Son of Heaven's state and has many famous vessels and precious treasures. If you hold your troops and do not deploy them, you can win Eastern Zhou's gratitude, and Western Zhou's treasures can surely all be obtained."

sentences.zh: 代見韓相國曰：「楚圍雍氏，期三月也，今五月不能拔，是楚病也。

sentences.zh: 韓相國大怒曰：「吾毋徵甲與粟於周亦已多矣，何故與周高都也？」

translations.text: The prime minister of Han became very angry and said: "That I do not requisition armor and grain from Zhou is already generous; why would I give Gaodu to Zhou?"

sentences.zh: 代曰：「與周高都，是周折而入於韓也，秦聞之必大怒忿周，即不通周使，是以獘高都得完周也。

King Nan was called Chengjun. When Chu besieged Yongshi, Han requisitioned armor and grain from Eastern Zhou; the lord of Eastern Zhou was afraid, summoned Su Dai, and told him. Dai said: "Why should you be troubled by this, my lord? I can make Han not requisition armor and grain from Zhou, and I can also obtain Gaodu for you."  The lord of Zhou said: "If you can truly do this, I will let the state listen to you."  Dai met the prime minister of Han and said: "Chu besieged Yongshi with a deadline of three months, but now after five months cannot capture it; this shows Chu is weakened. Now the prime minister requisitions armor and grain from Zhou; this reveals to Chu that you are weakened."  The prime minister of Han said: "Good. But the envoy has already departed."  Dai said: "Why not give Gaodu to Zhou?"  The prime minister of Han became very angry and said: "That I do not requisition armor and grain from Zhou is already generous; why would I give Gaodu to Zhou?"  Dai said: "To give Gaodu to Zhou means Zhou will be bent and submit to Han; when Qin hears of this they will surely be greatly angered at Zhou and will then not communicate with Zhou's envoys; this way you give up a weakened Gaodu and obtain an intact Zhou. Why not give it?"  The prime minister said: "Good."  Indeed, he gave Gaodu to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 三十四年，蘇厲謂周君曰：「秦破韓、魏，撲師武，北取趙藺、離石者，皆白起也。

translations.text: In the thirty-fourth year, Su Li said to the lord of Zhou: "That Qin defeated Han and Wei, destroyed the army at Shiwu, and took Lin and Lishi from Zhao in the north was all due to Bai Qi.

sentences.zh: 是善用兵，又有天命。

translations.text: He is skilled at using troops and also has Heaven's mandate.

sentences.zh: 今又將兵出塞攻梁，梁破則周危矣。

translations.text: Now he is about to lead troops out of the passes to attack Liang; if Liang is broken, Zhou will be in danger.

sentences.zh: 君何不令人說白起乎？

translations.text: Why don't you have someone persuade Bai Qi?

sentences.zh: 曰『楚有養由基者，善射者也。

translations.text: Say: 'Chu had Yang Youji, who was an excellent archer.

sentences.zh: 去柳葉百步而射之，百發而百中之。

translations.text: At a hundred paces from willow leaves he shot at them, and out of a hundred shots hit every one.

sentences.zh: 左右觀者數千人，皆曰善射。

translations.text: Several thousand observers on both sides all said he was an excellent archer.

sentences.zh: 有一夫立其旁，曰「善，可教射矣」。

translations.text: There was one man standing beside him who said: 'Good, but you can still be taught archery.'

sentences.zh: 養由基怒，釋弓搤劍，曰「客安能教我射乎」？

translations.text: Yang Youji became angry, put down his bow, grasped his sword, and said: 'How can you, guest, teach me archery?'

sentences.zh: 客曰「非吾能教子支左詘右也。

translations.text: The guest said: 'It is not that I can teach you to extend left and bend right.

sentences.zh: 夫去柳葉百步而射之，百發而百中之，不以善息，少焉氣衰力倦，弓撥矢鉤，一發不中者，百發盡息」。

translations.text: At a hundred paces from willow leaves you shoot at them, and out of a hundred shots hit every one; if you do not rest when you are shooting well, soon your energy will decline and strength weaken, the bow will be deflected and arrows will hook; if one shot misses, all hundred shots will be wasted.'

sentences.zh: 今破韓、魏，撲師武，北取趙藺、離石者，公之功多矣。

translations.text: Now that you have defeated Han and Wei, destroyed the army at Shiwu, and taken Lin and Lishi from Zhao in the north, your merits are many.

sentences.zh: 今又將兵出塞，過兩周，倍韓，攻梁，一舉不得，前功盡棄。

translations.text: Now you are about to lead troops out of the passes, pass through the Two Zhous, turn your back on Han, and attack Liang; if one campaign fails, all previous achievements will be abandoned.

sentences.zh: 公不如稱病而無出』。」

translations.text: You would be better off claiming illness and not going out.'"

In the thirty-fourth year, Su Li said to the lord of Zhou: "That Qin defeated Han and Wei, destroyed the army at Shiwu, and took Lin and Lishi from Zhao in the north was all due to Bai Qi. He is skilled at using troops and also has Heaven's mandate. Now he is about to lead troops out of the passes to attack Liang; if Liang is broken, Zhou will be in danger. Why don't you have someone persuade Bai Qi? Say: 'Chu had Yang Youji, who was an excellent archer. At a hundred paces from willow leaves he shot at them, and out of a hundred shots hit every one. Several thousand observers on both sides all said he was an excellent archer. There was one man standing beside him who said: 'Good, but you can still be taught archery.' Yang Youji became angry, put down his bow, grasped his sword, and said: 'How can you, guest, teach me archery?' The guest said: 'It is not that I can teach you to extend left and bend right. At a hundred paces from willow leaves you shoot at them, and out of a hundred shots hit every one; if you do not rest when you are shooting well, soon your energy will decline and strength weaken, the bow will be deflected and arrows will hook; if one shot misses, all hundred shots will be wasted.' Now that you have defeated Han and Wei, destroyed the army at Shiwu, and taken Lin and Lishi from Zhao in the north, your merits are many. Now you are about to lead troops out of the passes, pass through the Two Zhous, turn your back on Han, and attack Liang; if one campaign fails, all previous achievements will be abandoned. You would be better off claiming illness and not going out.'"

sentences.zh: 四十二年，秦破華陽約。

translations.text: In the forty-second year, Qin broke the Huayang treaty.

sentences.zh: 馬犯謂周君曰：「請令梁城周。」

translations.text: Ma Fan said to the lord of Zhou: "Let me have Liang fortify Zhou."

sentences.zh: 乃謂梁王曰：「周王病若死，則犯必死矣。

translations.text: He then said to the King of Liang: "If the King of Zhou is sick and dies, then Fan will surely die.

sentences.zh: 犯請以九鼎自入於王，王受九鼎而圖犯。」

translations.text: Fan requests to personally bring the Nine Tripods to you; when you receive the Nine Tripods, plan for Fan."

sentences.zh: 梁王曰：「善。」

translations.text: The King of Liang said: "Excellent."

sentences.zh: 遂與之卒，言戍周。

translations.text: He then gave him troops, ostensibly to garrison Zhou.

sentences.zh: 因謂秦王曰：「梁非戍周也，將伐周也。

translations.text: Then he said to the King of Qin: "Liang is not garrisoning Zhou; they will attack Zhou.

sentences.zh: 王試出兵境以觀之。」

translations.text: Your Majesty, try deploying troops at the border to observe."

sentences.zh: 秦果出兵。

translations.text: Qin indeed deployed troops.

sentences.zh: 又謂梁王曰：「周王病甚矣，犯請後可而復之。

translations.text: He also said to the King of Liang: "The King of Zhou is very ill; Fan requests to wait until later when it is feasible and report back.

sentences.zh: 今王使卒之周，諸侯皆生心，後舉事且不信。

translations.text: Now that you have sent troops to Zhou, all the feudal lords have become suspicious, and later when you undertake matters they will not trust you.

sentences.zh: 不若令卒為周城，以匿事端。」

translations.text: It would be better to have the troops fortify Zhou, to conceal the true intention."

sentences.zh: 梁王曰：「善。」

translations.text: The King of Liang said: "Good."

sentences.zh: 遂使城周。

translations.text: He then had them fortify Zhou.

In the forty-second year, Qin broke the Huayang treaty. Ma Fan said to the lord of Zhou: "Let me have Liang fortify Zhou."  He then said to the King of Liang: "If the King of Zhou is sick and dies, then Fan will surely die. Fan requests to personally bring the Nine Tripods to you; when you receive the Nine Tripods, plan for Fan."  The King of Liang said: "Excellent."  He then gave him troops, ostensibly to garrison Zhou. Then he said to the King of Qin: "Liang is not garrisoning Zhou; they will attack Zhou. Your Majesty, try deploying troops at the border to observe."  Qin indeed deployed troops. He also said to the King of Liang: "The King of Zhou is very ill; Fan requests to wait until later when it is feasible and report back. Now that you have sent troops to Zhou, all the feudal lords have become suspicious, and later when you undertake matters they will not trust you. It would be better to have the troops fortify Zhou, to conceal the true intention."  The King of Liang said: "Good."  He then had them fortify Zhou.

sentences.zh: 四十五年，周君之秦客謂周（最）［聚］曰：「公不若譽秦王之孝，因以應為太后養地，秦王必喜，是公有秦交。

translations.text: In the forty-fifth year, a guest of the lord of Zhou in Qin said to Zhou Ju: "You should praise the filial piety of the King of Qin and accordingly agree to provide lands to support the Queen Mother; the King of Qin will surely be pleased, and thus you will have Qin's friendship.

sentences.zh: 交善，周君必以為公功。

translations.text: If relations are good, the lord of Zhou will surely consider it your achievement.

sentences.zh: 交惡，勸周君入秦者必有罪矣。」

translations.text: If relations are bad, those who urged the lord of Zhou to go to Qin will surely be blamed."

sentences.zh: 秦攻周，而周聚謂秦王曰：「為王計者不攻周。

translations.text: When Qin attacked Zhou, Zhou Ju said to the King of Qin: "In planning for you, one should not attack Zhou.

sentences.zh: 攻周，實不足以利，聲畏天下。

translations.text: Attacking Zhou brings no real benefit but will make all under Heaven fear your reputation.

sentences.zh: 天下以聲畏秦，必東合於齊。

translations.text: When all under Heaven fears Qin's reputation, they will surely unite with Qi in the east.

sentences.zh: 兵獘於周。

translations.text: Your troops will be weakened at Zhou.

translations.text: If all under Heaven unites with Qi, then Qin will not become king.

sentences.zh: 天下欲獘秦，勸王攻周。

translations.text: All under Heaven wants to weaken Qin and urges you to attack Zhou.

sentences.zh: 秦與天下獘，則令不行矣。」

translations.text: If Qin and all under Heaven are both weakened, then your commands will not be carried out."

In the forty-fifth year, a guest of the lord of Zhou in Qin said to Zhou Ju: "You should praise the filial piety of the King of Qin and accordingly agree to provide lands to support the Queen Mother; the King of Qin will surely be pleased, and thus you will have Qin's friendship. If relations are good, the lord of Zhou will surely consider it your achievement. If relations are bad, those who urged the lord of Zhou to go to Qin will surely be blamed."  When Qin attacked Zhou, Zhou Ju said to the King of Qin: "In planning for you, one should not attack Zhou. Attacking Zhou brings no real benefit but will make all under Heaven fear your reputation. When all under Heaven fears Qin's reputation, they will surely unite with Qi in the east. Your troops will be weakened at Zhou. If all under Heaven unites with Qi, then Qin will not become king. All under Heaven wants to weaken Qin and urges you to attack Zhou. If Qin and all under Heaven are both weakened, then your commands will not be carried out."

sentences.zh: 五十八年，三晉距秦。

translations.text: In the fifty-eighth year, the Three Jin resisted Qin.

sentences.zh: 周令其相國之秦，以秦之輕也，還其行。

translations.text: Zhou ordered its prime minister to go to Qin, but considering Qin to be of little importance, halted the journey.

sentences.zh: 客謂相國曰：「秦之輕重未可知也。

translations.text: A guest said to the prime minister: "Qin's importance cannot yet be known.

sentences.zh: 秦欲知三國之情。

translations.text: Qin wants to know the situation of the three states.

sentences.zh: 公不如急見秦王曰『請為王聽東方之變』，秦王必重公。

translations.text: You should quickly meet the King of Qin and say: 'Let me observe developments in the east for you'; the King of Qin will surely value you.

sentences.zh: 重公，是秦重周，周以取秦也；

translations.text: If he values you, that means Qin values Zhou, and Zhou thereby gains Qin;

sentences.zh: 齊重，則固有周聚以收齊：是周常不失重國之交也。」

translations.text: if Qi values Zhou, then Zhou surely has Zhou Ju to win over Qi: thus Zhou never loses the friendship of powerful states."

sentences.zh: 秦信周，發兵攻三晉。

translations.text: Qin trusted Zhou and mobilized troops to attack the Three Jin.

In the fifty-eighth year, the Three Jin resisted Qin. Zhou ordered its prime minister to go to Qin, but considering Qin to be of little importance, halted the journey. A guest said to the prime minister: "Qin's importance cannot yet be known. Qin wants to know the situation of the three states. You should quickly meet the King of Qin and say: 'Let me observe developments in the east for you'; the King of Qin will surely value you. If he values you, that means Qin values Zhou, and Zhou thereby gains Qin; if Qi values Zhou, then Zhou surely has Zhou Ju to win over Qi: thus Zhou never loses the friendship of powerful states."  Qin trusted Zhou and mobilized troops to attack the Three Jin.

sentences.zh: 五十九年，秦取韓陽城負黍，西周恐，倍秦，與諸侯約從，將天下銳師出伊闕攻秦，令秦無得通陽城。

translations.text: In the fifty-ninth year, Qin took Yangcheng and Fushu from Han; Western Zhou was afraid, turned against Qin, made a vertical alliance with the feudal lords, led the elite forces of all under Heaven out through Yique to attack Qin, and ordered that Qin not be allowed to reach Yangcheng.

sentences.zh: 秦昭王怒，使將軍摎攻西周。

translations.text: King Zhao of Qin became angry and sent General Jiu to attack Western Zhou.

sentences.zh: 西周君犇秦，頓首受罪，盡獻其邑三十六，口三萬。

translations.text: The lord of Western Zhou fled to Qin, bowed his head to receive punishment, and offered all his thirty-six towns and thirty thousand people.

sentences.zh: 秦受其獻，歸其君於周。

translations.text: Qin accepted his offerings and returned his lord to Zhou.

In the fifty-ninth year, Qin took Yangcheng and Fushu from Han; Western Zhou was afraid, turned against Qin, made a vertical alliance with the feudal lords, led the elite forces of all under Heaven out through Yique to attack Qin, and ordered that Qin not be allowed to reach Yangcheng. King Zhao of Qin became angry and sent General Jiu to attack Western Zhou. The lord of Western Zhou fled to Qin, bowed his head to receive punishment, and offered all his thirty-six towns and thirty thousand people. Qin accepted his offerings and returned his lord to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 周君、王赧卒，周民遂東亡。

translations.text: When the lord of Zhou, King Nan, died, the people of Zhou then fled eastward.

sentences.zh: 秦取九鼎寶器，而遷西周公於憚狐。

translations.text: Qin took the Nine Tripods and precious vessels and relocated the duke of Western Zhou to Danhu.

sentences.zh: 後七歲，秦莊襄王滅東（西）周。

translations.text: Seven years later, King Zhuangxiang of Qin destroyed Eastern Zhou.

sentences.zh: 東西周皆入于秦，周既不祀。

translations.text: Eastern and Western Zhou both fell to Qin, and Zhou's sacrifices ceased.

When the lord of Zhou, King Nan, died, the people of Zhou then fled eastward. Qin took the Nine Tripods and precious vessels and relocated the duke of Western Zhou to Danhu. Seven years later, King Zhuangxiang of Qin destroyed Eastern Zhou. Eastern and Western Zhou both fell to Qin, and Zhou's sacrifices ceased.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：學者皆稱周伐紂，居洛邑，綜其實不然。

translations.text: The Grand Historian says: Scholars all say that after Zhou defeated Zhou, they resided at Luoyi, but examining the facts, this is not so.

sentences.zh: 武王營之，成王使召公卜居，居九鼎焉，而周復都豐、鎬。

translations.text: King Wu planned it, King Cheng had the Duke of Shao divine about residing there and placed the Nine Tripods there, but Zhou returned its capital to Feng and Hao.

sentences.zh: 至犬戎敗幽王，周乃東徙于洛邑。

translations.text: It was not until the Quanrong defeated King You that Zhou moved east to Luoyi.

sentences.zh: 所謂「周公葬（我）［於］畢」，畢在鎬東南杜中。

translations.text: The so-called "the Duke of Zhou was buried at Bi"—Bi is in Du, southeast of Hao.

sentences.zh: 秦滅周。

translations.text: Qin destroyed Zhou.

sentences.zh: 漢興九十有餘載，天子將封泰山，東巡狩至河南，求周苗裔，封其後嘉三十里地，號曰周子南君，比列侯，以奉其先祭祀。

translations.text: More than ninety years after the rise of Han, when the Son of Heaven was about to perform the feng sacrifice at Mount Tai, he made an eastern inspection tour to Henan, sought out Zhou's descendants, enfeoffed their heir Jia with thirty li of land, titled him Lord Zinan of Zhou, ranked him with the marquises, to continue the sacrifices to their ancestors.

The Grand Historian says: Scholars all say that after Zhou defeated Zhou, they resided at Luoyi, but examining the facts, this is not so. King Wu planned it, King Cheng had the Duke of Shao divine about residing there and placed the Nine Tripods there, but Zhou returned its capital to Feng and Hao. It was not until the Quanrong defeated King You that Zhou moved east to Luoyi. The so-called "the Duke of Zhou was buried at Bi"—Bi is in Du, southeast of Hao. Qin destroyed Zhou. More than ninety years after the rise of Han, when the Son of Heaven was about to perform the feng sacrifice at Mount Tai, he made an eastern inspection tour to Henan, sought out Zhou's descendants, enfeoffed their heir Jia with thirty li of land, titled him Lord Zinan of Zhou, ranked him with the marquises, to continue the sacrifices to their ancestors.
